content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												They introduced an EULA after the fact which includes parts that directly violate any consideration for data protection. In there they allow themselves and "third parties" to mine your data in a lot of ways. They also allow themselves to change it again whenever they want. If you don't agree, you lose access to your tables and can't play anymore. That's absolutely unacceptable behavior in my opinion.Introducing an EULA after the fact is unacceptable on its own without offering a full refund since I couldn't have known about the new EULA when I bought the tables. But then even adding such privacy violating terms that's the last straw.And they closed a thread in the forums here, where it was discussed with no good reason at all.All in all I'm disgusted by their behavior and I therefore regret the money I put into this game. If I had known what I know now, I wouldn't have bought any of the tables.EDIT 05.07.2015: They promised a revised EULA. Nothing happened. We have been waiting since May 12, 2015 now. That's when the new EULA was introduced. So we have been waiting for almost 8 weeks now to play the game we paid (a lot of) money for. And the only thing that happens is they lock threads where this is talked about.My advice would be to ask for a refund for every table now. It's been long enough waiting for them to resolve this, they had plenty of time and did nothing. Changing the EULA after the fact should be reason enough to get a refund even if you have played the game for more than 2 hours before the EULA change.EDIT 15.08.2015: As of today, more than 3 months after the newly introduced EULA, nothing  substantial has changed. I'm still locked out of the game I purchased (through DLC, game itself is marketed as F2P) without having to agree to any EULA at all and still can't play without accepting one now which still has questionable parts I don't want to agree to.Again we're promised major changes for the better in the forum and there's a discussion about that existing customers shouldn't have seen the new EULA pop up at all. But we have. And we can't play without accepting it.Well, we'll see where it all leads, but in any case, it's been more than THREE MONTHS without a solution which says a lot in my opinion. I would still like to see a good solution though, obviously, which should be: Anyone who bought the game (which essentially means DLC for the game) before they introduced the new EULA (any EULA at all) should be able to play the game without the enforcement of said EULA. Any new buyers should at least be shown the EULA BEFORE they buy/download the game. I have no idea how they would do that technically, distinguishing these two types of players ingame, however. So even better: Drop that EULA crap completely, like almost every other game does.Edit 17.09.2015: Still no update, although they promised again and again. Instead they locked the "New EULA" thread again. Why? Because in there they were called again on their let's name it "misbehaviour", you all know what I would rather name it, but I'll try to be civil here although they aren't. The Community Manager for Zen Studios Barbie Bob-omb says it's locked because of arguing (which is exactly what that thread and a forum is for) and to avoid banning, so clearly threatens to ban (without a good reason). Clearly the real reason is to have that thread disappear on the second page again. It's not the first time they did it (see above). They even ban people for voicing their  opinion.So we are at 4 ( in words: four ! ) months waiting time for them to solve this now. I'm starting to miss the right words to express how disgusted I am about their behaviour in this whole matter. That includes their forum moderation.One thing's for sure, whatever they do now, I will avoid them like the plague in the future. They will never see another cent from me. I know that's not helping to motivate them to solve this, but I'm just done with them. I've never seen a developer/publisher treat their customers with that much disrespect over such a long time. And I've seen a lot of crap in that regard.EDIT: 02.10.2015: One last edit. After 4.5 months they finally admitted that the new EULA is here to stay even for existing customers. So I won't be able to play this game ever again although it was paid a lot of money for. I don't have to tell you how much that sucks.I recommend everyone to ask Steam for a refund. If you refer to the new EULA, where there wasn't one when you bought the game, in your request for a refund, Steam should approve your request even though you probably played a lot longer than two hours. Unfortunately I got all my tables as gifts and Steam doesn't do refunds for gifts, so I can't ask for one. Otherwise I would have done so months ago and not wasted so much time trying to debate with this rotten developer.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												So I grew up around real-life pinball tables yet never spent much time on them.  The reason is that I had 'better' things to do at the arcade: Space Invaders, Asteroids, Galaga, Paperboy, Double Dragon, etc. were all more important to me than pinball.  But this game has me wishing that wasn't the case! In fact, if I had a time machine I would go back and try all of those tables in real life!I know I haven't said much about the game itself, and I'm not going to either.  The truth is I don't even know much about pinball.  I'll just give you a couple reasons why I think this game is such a success to me:--each table feels genuinely different which adds to replayability--the leaderboard system is great: it got me to add friends for chasing high scores and I've also been telling family members to try this out--there's nothing like beating your sister or cousin or even long lost uncle!--everyone gets a free table, which is a pretty good one in and of itself (just try it!)--love the sound bytes (especially for Star Wars tables) as they really add to the overall atmosphere--it's still fun even if your not very good at it (like me)--it got me to write this review

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Ever since I was a young boy, I played the silver ball.  No, wait, I'm thinking of Tommy.  Either way, pinball has been an important part of my life whenever it has been.  Time marches on though, and you can't just go play pinball like you used to.  Down at the local hangout, by the soda fountain, with flippers flipping, balls always bouncing, to the left and to the right, lights flashing, eplileptic kids flailing about on the floor, those days, back then, they're gone.     All is not lost though.  Pinball FX2 is here to fill that void left by the demise of the pinball machine with software pinball that surpasses the original in every way except for those it does not.  When it comes down to it, what you really lose is having an actual pinball table in front of you.  You can never recreate that exact feel, the solid wood gripped firmly in your hands as you aim for ever higher scores while deftly avoiding the flailing epileptic kids.     That's just the way it has to be though, and there are plenty of good things about virtual pinball that makes it well worth a play.  The tables can be more elaborate than a real pinball table ever could, and they certainly are lovely to look at.  Any pinball table you want is right there on your television, no need for a huge arcade to house all of your games.  Heck, with a wireless xbox controller, you even get some vibration when you shake the table.     If you loved pinball when you were a kid, or know someone who did, give Pinball FX2 a try.  It's the next best thing to being there again, reliving those memories, and best of all, you won't have to step over any epileptics to do it.

												Zen Studios did a great favor to all the digital pinball enthusiasts - they didn't go for a simulation.Let me explain it before I get back in the game. You can always try to be more realistic, more physics-respecting, more simulating game. And you will probably fail miserably because there's a sweet magic of analogue mechanisms of pinball machines no computer will be able to understand and process... EVER.BUT... if you take a concept of pinball game which says 'keep that ball up for as long as possible and score as many points as you possibly can', slap it on crazy fun tables with various themes and make playing digital pinball FUN thing to do, either solo or with friends - yes, you will be coming back for one more and yes, you will never stop.So, thank you, Zen Studios for nothing making Pinball FX2 mediocre simulation pinball game, but a super fun arcade pinball game.

number of helpful: 57 of 78 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												At launch, Pinball FX 2 was already a fantastic game. Originally released on the Xbox 360, it featured backwards compatibility with the original Pinball FX, and this allowed an already burgeoning title to be filled with even more Pinball goodness. As it stands, there are over 30 tables in the game as of this writing, and each and every one is free to try, with the standout Sorcerer's Lair being completely free.It's a little sad knowing that the arcade is no longer truly viable, and I'll never again experience the giddy joy of pumping coins into a table, longing for the extra ball and multiball modes we all love, or watching to see if the numbers matched and I won a free game. But while the arcade as a destination may be on it's final legs, the pinball experience presented in FX 2 is pure unadulterated joy. Those fond memories are brought to the forefront with this version, the ultimate version of Pinball FX 2. As a free download, this game should find a place in just about every gamer's library, and with tables based on many themes, there are sure to be some you'll love. Each table has their own achievements, backstory, missions, combos, and design.For most of the tables, the cost is approximate to what would cost a single game of pinball at the arcade, so value wise the game is excellent value. The hours upon hours of gameplay possibility and replayability is enormous, and there really is something for everyone here - from Ancient Rome to Boba Fett.In addition, the table design is above and beyond what can be done with conventional pinball, with full video mini games and hidden extras. Nothing is truly over the top, though there aren't any dead spots either. With seven angles to play from, and a free view angle to fly around the table close up, you'll find plenty to play for. Ramps, drop balls, lit targets, missions, and more are available on each table.Finely integrated leaderboards will see you play against friends and the community on each and every table, with an overall score representing your prowess across all tables. Local leaderboards and multiplayer should see FX 2 become a staple quick fire up and play at home as well.The sound and graphics are really well done - with the narrator both chastising and egging you on to play better, and with rewarding sound bites when you do well. The sound effects are particularly fantastic on Secrets of the Deep, an underwater themed table, and there are classic themes and sound effects on the Star Wars and Marvel themed tables, respectively. The game is a joy to watch in action. The design and execution of the tables really cannot be overstated. There are multiple views and options to tune the game to your liking, and the low requirements make this an ideal game for every steam user. Pinball FX 2 is a beautiful game, not just a beautiful pinball game.Overall this is a game too easy not to enjoy. The low cost and low barrier to entry make this an easy recommend, and the many hours of replayability, the freedom to pick up and play, and just the genuine fun available make this the best virtual pinball title ever made available. It's well worth your time.9.0/10.

number of helpful: 31 of 35 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												On Steam there is what I consider kind of a holy trinity of pinball games.If I want realism I go for Pinball Arcade and their collection of classic solid state tables.If I want something with a real challenge I go for Zaccaria and their more offbeat but still excellent European tables.On the other hand, if I want sheer creativity and the experience that makes the most of what video pinball has to offer... I turn to Pinball FX2.Where both Pinball Arcade and Zaccaria turn their sites toward emulating experiences of the past and trying to give users a taste of what classic arcade pinball was all about, Pinball FX2 takes full advantage of the opportunity to show what can be done with the basic concepts of the game when neither money nor physical limitations can get in the way of the experience. The result is tables that are fun first and foremost. Tables are liberal with their ball saves, kickbacks, and extra balls, with the goal being to direct your attention more toward the goals the tables ask you to accomplish rather than making you focus simply on keeping the ball in play. Tables feature animated props and backgrounds, and oftentimes integrate these animated elements into the gameplay itself, with lightsabers beaming your ball from one side of the playfield to another, starship battles, even monsters walking across the field begging you to destroy them.If Pinball FX2 has one area where it does suffer it would be in score bloat. Anyone with experience with actual pinball tables -- or even the other games mentioned above -- will immediately feel the modern bent of Pinball FX2's scoring treatment, with scores in the millions of points being common, even expected of players. This, combined with the game's relative ease in comparison to its competition, means that the leaderboards for the game are filled with seemingly impossible scores that often can represent hours of gameplay on a single table, even in a single session. As a result, score standing in the games is typically a product less of one's pinball skill and more of attrition, since many of the tables are gentle enough that a solid player will likely tire of playing before they're in any real danger of losing (Droids being a particularly bothersome table in this regard.)Pinball FX2 is a great pinball game for anyone looking more for a modernized, friendly experience rather than a more classically accurate one. Fun tables with a variety of themes and features impossible to replicate in an actual physical unit makes for a one-of-a-kind experience that almost anyone can enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												The days when we could go out with a pocket full of change and spend hours on end playing pinball at the arcades are long gone and apart from the odd pinball machine in a pub here and there most of us will have a hard time finding a real machine. If we want to play pinball today we probably have to do it virtually and Pinball FX2 delivers one of the most enjoyable virtual pinball experiences.I'm pretty sure the basic concept of pinball needs no introduction but just in case you've been living under rock: You use your flippers to direct a small steel ball around the pinball table and aim for different targets to score as many points as possible while at the same time you try to prevent the ball from falling into the drain or one of the side lanes.Pinball FX2 already offers a variety of tables and new ones are released regularly. All the tables differ widely from each other in terms of gameplay, looks and underlying theme. Some have a somewhat minimalistic layout with only few ramps and extras, others feel almost overloaded with features. Some are easy to get into, others are very challenging and have a steep learning curve. Fans of the Marvel and Star Wars franchises will be delighted to have the opportunity to choose from a selection of acordingly themed tables.You can compete with friends in local hotseat multiplayer matches or chase highscores to climb up local and online leaderboards but the competion gets most intense with friend score challenges when you have some other players in your Steam friendlist.The game supports keyboard, mouse and controller.Unlike Pinball Arcade (another great pinball simulation available right here on Steam), that offers authentic recreations of real-life tables licenced from pinball machine manufacturers, all Pinball FX2 tables are original creations by the games developer Zen Studios. This can be a drawback if you want to relive your pinball memories with your favourite tables from the past but it's also an advantage because it allows for more artistic freedom. A freedom the developers put to good use with stunning effects that wouldn't be physically possible in reality, like Marvel characters battling each other across the table, among other things.Additional tables come at a decent price, especially if you consider the many hours of entertainment that every single one provides. With the wide variety of genuinely different tables, everyone, casuals and hardcore pinball fanatics alike, will find some tailored to their individual taste. There's really no reason to hesitate to get some pinball action right away.

But in general do not support any Zen Studios products because they are likely to change your legal terms, say anything they want and you'll be forced to agree or lose your money.HUGE CON:Zen/Microsoft added a EULA to the title.  That in and of itself isn't the problem.  As long as the EULA was added BEOFRE consumers purchased the title that would be fine.  The problem is that they are holding every license/subscription hostage for all of the EXISTING consumers who owned this title BEFORE the EULA was added.  e.g. They added the EULA a few months ago and consumers are FORCED to agree to it before they can play the title again.  There's been a consistently ongoing discussion about their actions in http://steamcommunity.com/app/226980/discussions/0/620712999988337987.So do not support an anti-consumer, anti-EU laws, anti-moral compassed company.  They could have easily avoided this issue IF they left FX2 alone and created an FX3 which contained the EULA and let consumer DECIDE.The worst part is that when directly asked as per the instructions of the EULA, Zen will not disclose what it is they/3rd parties are collecting.PROS:Some tables were fun.  Not all.  But at least you could spend about 3 minutes trying each board before you purchased it.SUGGESTION to Steam & 3rd party Publishers/Developers:Steam/VALVe should reset the refund clock if a Publisher/Developer adds a EULA to a title AFTER the title has been released.  That way consumers can actually make a choice:A) 'I accepting your new legal terms' (and letting the publisher keep the spent money)ORB) 'I don't agree to your new terms' (and I'll be getting my money back.  You should have had the EULA when I originally purchased the title or learned not to add it post-sale.)

number of helpful: 25 of 33 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												I'm a pretty big fan of pinball. I'm not a big fan at all of Pinball FX and the tables therein. Visually, they're fantastic, but only if you're watching someone else. It's a real pain when Spider Man swings in front of your flippers, or you have massive explosions going off that distract your tracking from the hyper-kinetic ball. Pinball FX is not going for realism or emulating pinball, and is very much invested in maximizing the potential of digital pinball, thus the games feel faster than what you would see in traditional pinball, or even something like The Pinball Arcade. This is usually to the game's detriment, in my eyes.Personally, I dislike the feel of the game. At no point does the ball feel controllable, and in some instances, the physics are simply wrong or buggy. Drop catches and live catches are rare but seemingly possible; they don't seem like something you can actively do as the technique looks to me more of a strange collision bug than actual skill and timing.  I found myself having less fun playing the game due to inconsistencies in physics reactions, shots not registering, and collision bugs with flippers, ramps, other balls and walls. Table rules are deeper than necessary, requiring detailed study of the rule sheet. Which, by itself is fine, however there is a bit of an issue when you can't figure out what you need to shoot for due to information not being presented clearly by the game. Firing up a game and learning the rules intrinsically is just not going to happen. Additionally, many modes require simply grinding shots, which to me, is remarkably boring. Coupled with the shot registration bugs, actually working toward a mode or a strategy tends to be more infuriating than it's worth.Many of the tables borrow shot concepts from existing pinball tables, which is great! However, they seem to only have borrowed the mechanic, but have not paid any attention to ball flow and angle after the fact - many shots are simply drains waiting to happen. You are literally being punished with a ball drain for successfully making a shot. Additionally, some concepts are used, but simply fail to work. For instance, the Venom table looks to attempt the outlane gate nudge-back concept used on Bally's Centaur... which would be amazing if the designers understood that having the bounce post about a mile away from the gate and the sensitivity for tilting cranked on the game makes the gate-save concept useless.Overall, if you're looking for something different in the pinball space, try a table from Pinball FX, but do so knowing you're going to be playing tables made by people who don't seem to grasp the idea of game layout or rules design.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
Why not recommended:I played pinball for years when I was younger (as my dad worked in a bar part-time) and later I went through town to specific pinball tables.The tables in this game are purely fantasy. They could not be built in real life.And whats more: You play on a 2D table - and then 3D objects just pop up (like Plants vs. Zombies), which really.. does not match the feeling of a flat pinball table.Also you can feel that physics is nearly, but not exacly as in real life. Sometimes it feels to fast, then to slow, then you have camera zoom in on an element. All nicely done; all nothing to do with a real pinball table.So far the best virtual tables I know are still the old TimeShock! and bus driver thingy which name I don't remember right now. They are decades old and still look great; sadly do not come with high res/controller support (which is why I tried this one) and don't work as nicely on some machines due to DOS emulation :-/Why you might still like it:Pinball tables are nicely designed, have lots of different elements (although some feel generic) and use their specific themed sounds, graphics etc. So if you know the movie/game the table is based on, it does provide a nice "ahh, I know that" feeling.Also I did not encounter any performance issues or bugs, controller handling is fine, too.So if you don't mind the not-quite-real-feeling, you can give it a try, as it is not a rip-off or anything. Just not what I am looking for/prefer.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												I wouldn't have written this review, but I wanted to hopefully share some sanity to the recent reviews for one of my favorite games.Anybody who is afraid of this "terrible bad datamining EULA that transmits your passwords" should read the EULA and privacy policy for themselves. Maybe it was worse before, and maybe they changed it. There's no "virus miner" and certainly no terms in the EULA to allow them putting one in. This is how the EULA stands currently, in layman's terms:* If you access their website, they will give you cookies* If you sign up for ZEN services, they will store your username, profile avatar, and ZEN password* If you use non-steam versions of Pinball FX2, they will show you targetted advertising (They included permission to do this in Steam too, but I don't notice any ads in the game)* If you provide any information or make any forum posts, they will store that information and analyze it for ads. They may disclose it to third parties. If you don't want people seeing your information, don't share it.* They reserve the right to store more data than what they mentioned, but unless you're a conspiracy theorist, you will hopefully understand that they don't have the physical ability to store more data than what you provide to them. People have claimed that the game contains a data miner, but haven't provided any evidence other than the EULA saying they share your data with third parties.Their full privacy policy is here: http://blog.zenstudios.com/privacy_policy_pc_steam.html And the EULA, which is a blanket that covers ZEN software in general, is in the yellow box to the right of the steam page.Yes, they use the data you provide them, and yes, they will target ads (if you view their website and affiliated ads on the net), but this is completely ordinary nowadays. Just look at the EULA for any AAA publisher and they'll cover their bases in a similar way.As for the game itself, it's great. The free table is very enjoyable, and I always come back to it, despite owning a lot of the paid ones. The physics are good, though the ball could feel a bit more weighty IMO. It's a fairly videogamey sort of pinball. It's definitely not a simulator like Pinball Arcade or Timeshock.Give the game a try if you like pinball!

number of helpful: 62 of 106 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												I've played many real and video pinball machines over the years and, to be totally honest, while the tables in Pinball FX2 are beautiful and make good use of modern video game graphics, there are issues that make the game less than stellar (and even less than playable) in my book.First and foremost, the flippers are apparently insanely powerful. I've played pinball machines with strong flippers, but these are just impossible. Even on the near end of the flipper, the ball is launched off of it with nearly the same or exactly the same speed as if you flipped it from the distant end. Second, and nearly as bad, is the ball itself has just the most baffling physical properties. When you strike it with the flippers, it feels almost hollow and just flies off, even on top of the flipper hinge, even if you're trying not to even move the ball at all. If you try to catch the ball by holding the flipper when it comes down one of the side lanes, it rolls completely off the end of the flipper, every single time. You can flip it cleanly up a normal ramp and it will stop dead not even an inch up the ramp as if it lost momentum from spinning/rubbing against the side of the ramp, but then it comes straight back at nearly the same speed it had when you struck it (which is to say, maximum speed, because it always seems to be moving very fast), almost like you flipped it up a 60° incline with no friction at all. This happens in exceedingly random fashion as well; you can hit the same ramp at the same speed and it can go up normally...or not. There doesn't appear to be any rhyme or reason to it.Now, those things on their face make the game unplayable for me. If the underlying physics of the game engine behaved in a predictable way, it might have been different. The table designs themselves look pretty nice. That said, the dichotomy between the free table's design features that are reminiscent of actual pinball machine designs from the 90's and the essentially impossible design features that are only possible because it's a video game are a bit off-putting. I would prefer a table that's designed one way or the other. Especially if I'm going to be asked to put my initials into the Sorcerer's Lair table with the flipper buttons like some kind of non-keyboard-having troglodyte, a table that if it existed in reality would have to be LITERALLY haunted in order to have the same kinds of display features. The camera could use some work too, and yes, I tried all of the different view settings, none of them really helped me, especially when it came to trying to gauge distance on skill shots.Given the amount of graphical polish in the game, I really have to wonder how it ended up being this way. I was excited to try the game because the tables look beautiful and well designed, but instead I came away with that weird feeling of disappointment mixed with doubt that makes me wonder if I should keep trying it once again to see if my perception was incorrect. Unfortunately, I kept coming away with the same conclusions each time. Well, at least there's a free table.Edit: Haters gonna hate. I consider the downvotes validation of everything I said, and you should too. Clarified physics complaints slightly and made other minor changes. Moved edit info to bottom.

Each machine is configured differently and follows a theme, there are some neat little bonuses that work sort of like mini games, and they also have objectives marked out on the top left to let you know when you've done something right and how to proceed.  All in all I feel a robust 3d pinball game that offers you the choice of your favorite theme and leaderboard for both people on the same computer but steam friends as well.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2013
												Barely started playing it but this is a quality pinball game. The game isn't a real 'pinball simulation' but the gameplay is tight, holds true to it's own brand of physics and it adds gameplay elements impossible to implement in real tables. Basically unless you dislike anything but true to life pinball and 100% accurate simulations based on that, you should really, really enjoy this game and the one free table is awesome so... just do it. Also if you got windows 8 you can install this game through games for windows and get the MARS table for free as well which is also excellent.Update xmas 2013...Yeah this game is awesome. Some tables are better than others but overall this thing gets video game pinball right and plays to the strenght of the platform adding cool gameplay mechanics that take full advantage of the virtual medium... so get it if you like good games that reward skill play (well in most cases).

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
 Pinball FX2 Lets all play Pinball FX2, today, tomorrow, and who knows maybe next week and next year and so on. The best way for me to discribe Pinball FX2 is that it has been washed, scrubed and blow dryed and now its been refreshed and revitalised. I myself like to play Pinball for pure fun and joy and if I get a great score Im happy, but if not then Im still happy I had my few hours enjoyment and satisfaction. I only play Pinball if Im in the right mood anyway, as Im not a pro at it, and nor do I want to be. But I do love and admire all the great scores my friends share on it, and I know they enjoyed thier time playing the game and so earning those genuine and honest fantastic scores. It takes a great deal of consentration, very good fine motor skills and plenty and I mean plenty of constant practice and patience to become a Pinball King and or Wizard to be the best of the best and we have plenty of fantastic best of the best Pinballers that have put thier hearts and soles and many, many hundreds and thousands of hours into the game to master it and they do it ever so well, and who knows i could become 1 too some day. But Im not going to, because its way out of my league anyway, and Im not as passionate as others are. With regards to these tables and my personal experiance with these tables, is that I have prefered them over any other Pinball tables that steam has to offer, and thats not ment to put other companys down niether. I personally like and prefere most of Pinball FX tables but some are more prefered and fun than others and we all have our personal favourites and thats fine too.Im not a Pro Pinball play and so I cant explain the game play as such, just that Pinball is Pinball, and I love these Pinball tables. I am very proud to have some of the much loved best of the best Pinball players as my friends and I hope and pray that they never give up, and keep striving to be the best of the best and perhaps just take much needed breaks as I do when required as breaks are very important in life, they help clear the air and make way for fresh vitalised restarts ;)Dont give up on Pinball FX, give the game a go. The game is not easy, nor is it difficult as such, and it may not be for everyone. But the game sure is a lot of fun if you can get into it. I cant get the big scores, but it sure is fun trying to achieve and aim for your next more improved score anyway.Im going to give Pinball FX2 a 9/10If you dont agree, thats fine too.

number of helpful: 21 of 37 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I love playing FX2 Pinball!BUT…….!!! WARNING !!!Please be aware that, even though the Store Page makes no mention, every Zen Studios FX2 Pinball table or package you buy is actually “early access”, and as such is almost guaranteed to not only have bugs (not just on new tables, but also old and unfixed bugs on tables well over a year old), but most tables continue to generate a more or less constant stream of new bug issues (over 200 since 10/2015.) Zen does little or nothing to notify players when (or IF) problems are ever resolved. I have more than 825 games, yet Zen Studios, FX2 Pinball remains one of the worst, least responsive, most deliberately unpleasant and obtuse Steam vendors I’ve had the displeasure to encounter. I have gone from quite certainly being among the MOST supportive of FX2 players, to perhaps the MOST bitterly disappointed.And if you raise questions, be prepared to be treated as "enemy", as has been the case for numerous of Zen's most concerned and passionate customers, in a bizarre business strategy I've not encountered before in nearly 40 years in business.I love playing most of these tables, but no one should buy them without being aware of the potential for failure and frustration, and the possibility your scores will never even be recorded properly. As well, Zen Studies has, in the past 6 months alone (since approx.. mid ’15) wiped ALL scores for EVERY player on one table (Avengers – Ultron), and on EVERY one of 55 tables for EVERY player in another score wipe shortly after. This effectively eliminated up to two year’s efforts or more for 202,000 customers, including many disabled players. In doing so, Zen accused players of cheating for utilizing a specific pinball attribute that Zen themselves enabled, and is still available on other FX2 platforms other than Steam. Numerous of the world’s best players, and most helpful and conscientious of pinball advocates, left in protest, abandoning all hope of making use of their OWN significant financial and time investments.Following the SECOND Steam score wipe (early Oct. ‘15) which Zen Studios repeatedly promised NOT to perform, 90%, or 180,000 registered players, had NOT returned in the 3 months following.But if you love pinball as much as I do, this is simply a very annoying, irritating and frustrating price to be paid. But enough is enough…….Thank you.

number of helpful: 27 of 49 people (55%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												I have played alot of pinball in my life, starting with real pin tables in the 1960s. I buy every pinball game I can find, regardless of platform. Pinball FX2 is perhaps the very best virtual pinball game that I have ever played. Let it be known though that there are currently 57 tables available on Steam counting all 8 Super League Football (Soccer) team variants, and I own them all. On October 21st of this year they will release four more tables in a pack. More on those tables in a moment.Unlike many virtual pinball games the table designs and ball physics are rock-solid. Approx. 30% of their tables are totally original, as in non-licensed. My personal favorite of these is Socerer's Lair. In the interest of completness my least favorite of these is V12, but it may be just me as it's really hard for me to score well on this table. There are two South Park tables, which I love. My favorite is South Park's Super Sweet Pinball. I can spend hours playing that one. There is also a Portal table, which some gamers think of as Portal 3, because it takes place after the events of Portal 2. There is also a table based on The Walking Dead and one, which I love alot, based on the video game franchise Splosion Man. Well, more closely on the second game in the series Ms. Splosion Man, which is what it's called. It has a very anime feel to it that I like. It also reminds me abit of the Sega game for the Dreamcast Space Channel 5.Disney must love Zen Studios, as approx. 60% of the tables are either based on Star Wars or on Marvel comics and/or films and TV series. Zen recently renewed their licensing agreement for both franchises. Overall these tables range from good to excellent. Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back is one of the really good ones, with alot of mini-games. Darth Vader has a stand out line in this one - "I'm altering the game. Pray I don't alter it further." :)Zen Studios has added a new source to license properties for their tables from, Fox Digital. This is where the newest tables come in, to be released on Steam on October 21st as part of a four table pack entitled "Balls of Glory." Reminds me of the old virtual pinball game "Balls of Steel." The pack to be sold on Steam is rumored to sell for $9.95, which is very reasonable. The tables are American Dad Pinball, Archer Pinball, Bob's Burgers Pinball, and Family Guy Pinball. All are based on Fox animated TV series, although Archer airs on FX and FXX (both Fox owned). This deal opens the door for The Simpsons Pinball and Futurama Pinball. In fact it opens the door to alot of possibilities.There are only two downsides to Pinball FX2, and that is the EULA and the recent Leaderboards reset. Both bother many. Neither bothers me. The amount of data you fork over isn't nearly as much as is the case with the Steam version of Dream Pinball 3D (see my review), and Pinball FX2 is more stable. In fact it has never crashed on me - ever! The Leaderboards were reset to fix a bug that Zen discovered in the game. Rather than leave it in they took it out, but decided in fairness that this fix, which took out some exploits, made the tables harder to score on, at least for those (like me) who didn't even know that they were there. So they reset the Leaderboards. But they retained the old ones, called Legacy Leaderboards. The Local scores achieved in Hotseat Mode where left intact. If you don't like the EULA I don't recall there being one with the Android Apps.There is one Zen table currently unavailable on Steam as it is an Xbox 360 exclusive, and that's Rocky & Bullwinkle. Alot of people, including myself, have requested this table. But Zen no longer has the franchise rights, which means in order for them to release it on Steam they would have to renew that license. I hope they do. In 1993 Data East released a real pin machine, The Adventures of Rocky & Bullwinkle & Friends, but FarSight hasn't released it yet as part of their The Pinball Arcade game. I hope they will. They've been releasing more Data East tables of late. But I digress.Zen Studios must be doing something right. They started off with 4 employees and now have 75 (see the article on Zen Studios in the June 2015 issue of Game Informer magazine for more information. That would be issue #266).  Zen supports alot of platforms. In addition to the PC via Steam, the "Balls of Glory" pack of tables will be released for iOS, Android (the trailers are already on my Android device in the Zen Pinball app), the PS3, PS4, PS Vita, and the Xbox one. They have more Marvel, Star Wars, and originals confirmed.The controls are quite good, both with Keyboard and Control Pad. I am currently using a Logitech Xbox 360 controller set for X Mode, although D Mode does work as well. Not all games seem to be compatible with D Mode, but as I stated Pinball FX2 is. I use X Mode simply because it's compatible with most other games.Currently 150 friends on Steam own this game.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												It's a pretty good game of pinball. Specifically, video game pinball. The physics work pretty well, and the graphics are solid. Very rarely have I encountered a problem while playing. I can only remember one instance of a ball getting stuck because of a bug.  Edit: Something I wanted to point about my video game pinball comment. What I mean is that these tables are designed to be played longer than the real life counterpart(because they want your money of course). Therefore they have more extra balls you can earn, kickbacks and so on. You can even nudge the table in ways you couldn't do in real life, either because of personal injury or damaging the table itself. Be warned though, most tables will only give you two chances in a period of time before tilting out on you, but it sure can be fun to save a ball that otherwise would have been lost. One last thing that relates to the fact this is video game pinball, when you exit out a game in progress, the game will be saved, so don't worry if something comes up, or if you're just having a really good game but you can't play in one sitting.The one thing that appeals to me about pinball is that you're always trying to get better, so that you can continue to improve and of course get a better score. One thing that also helps is comparing how well you do with your friends. I have a number of Steam friends just so I can have scores to compare with and try to beat. I would say overall, the quality of the tables are fantastic. If I have any complaints, it's mostly about the selection-it's that Star Wars and Marvel theme tables dominate the catalog. Now don't get me wrong, I like Star Wars, and I love the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it would be cool to see different properties more often. (BTW, get Guardians of the Galaxy, and the Star Wars Balance of the Force pack-Starfighter Assault is my favorite table) I play with my X-Box 360 controller, it works really well with the game. I also have my second monitor on portrait mode, which makes a huge difference in seeing the table. If you can have that setup I totally recommend it.I never got to play real pinball that much, there's no arcades where I live, and of course getting a real machine is very expensive, so I think this is a good alternative. And the price for tables is decent.Also, there is a free table, and you can try all the tables to see what they're like. I recommend this game. Have fun, and may the bumpers be with you.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2013
												As a videogame (pinball or otherwise) available on Steam, this is one of the rare 10 out of 10 ways to spend your money.First, This game appeals to both the traditional "get-off-my-lawn" pinball wizard and the younger "never seen a real pin" crowd.Fantastic original table designs with satisfying rule-sets and replayability.Ball physics that nail the difficult to emulate real-world pinball experience without being artificially hard, and builds up the 'one-more-time' mentality with the occasional flirt into controller breaking frustration territory (but in a good way).Fantastic graphics and sound. Excellent use of licensed IP (though I prefer the original IP tables).Native Multi-Monitor Support (You can play this without much trouble on a Virtual Pin Cabinet).Wide range of gameplay within the table selection, though I do wish they would release a table or two that capture the EM feel. I buy all the tables and think they are all FUN, but if you are looking for a handful of real winners:Epic Quest - It isn't Medieval Madness but I get the same enjoyment.The (Your Team Here) Soccer Table - Fantastic goal oriented (pun intended) design.Plants verses Zombies - Another well defined rule-set with long-term playability.Thor - Excellent Ritchie like shot flow.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
10/10"Definately the best digital Pinball/Flipper you can get!"Pinball FX2 can easily keep up with the analog pinball machines, why?! It's much cheaper in the asset costs, the required space  is "1/30" if U own 30 tables & the specials of each table are just not possible on the old beloved pinball machines. If you like Pinball in general you will love Pinball FX2. Pinball fan since EPIC Pinball (1993). BUILD your own digital "physical" 32" pinball table ;)[www.instructables.com]Pros:+ THE best pinball out there+ great gameplay+ great tables (themes)+ great graphics+ great ost&sounds+ atmosphere+ challenging+ replayability+ world- &friend leaderboards+ 4K resolution support+ trying before buying (test every table)+ full X360 controller support (highly recom.)Cons:- You don't own the tables of the mobile versionMust Buy for every Pinball/Flipper Fan(Really great cost-benefit-ratio on sale!!!)

number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Whenever I'm upset playing other Steam oh-so-serious games, I run to casuals. PinballFX, honestly, is one of them.With the game, whether you just want to play the game casually, or to stomp your friends' high score, it's all catered. With tons of tables to play with (woooo thanks Humble Bundle) and well made tables, makes the experience fun.The gameplay is the same old, you only need to jump directly and play. All you need to do is to keep the ball inside your table and don't let it fall off. But unlike other pinball games I've played, this one offers an in-tables quests depending on where we aim the ball to thus makes the session more interesting to play and achieving higher personal scores isn't like a long mindless grind. And if you ever are confused with the tables, there's a help file (just pause the game and click on help) so you know of the table's objectives and on what to do.The tables designs are full with vibrant color and light, more than enough to please my eyes. And they're not fully static, with several addons side characters and mini tables (quest result), you're not just seeing a ball bouncing right and left.The tables are sold separately as 'DLC's. Make sure you read the appropriate store page of each DLC to know how many tables you're getting (yes, some are packaged together as one DLC, so 4 tables-for-one is not surprising). For tables reviews, refer to each Store Page's review, as it's too expansive to be reviewed in this single writing.Game natively supports local hot seat, but I personally would've liked to have a MP versus with friends thru internet, would've been much easier to play together. Not a big deal for missing the feature though.If you're unsure if you're interested enough, you can try the tables for a limited time and see for yourself. I personally haven't bought/gotten every single tables, but I'm quite sure the more tables I have, the merrier it will be.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This is a fast paced pinball game. The ball speed is faster compared to real pinball tables. Though weirdly, that doesn't seem to make it more difficult. It seems the tables are designed to compensate for that. It's also not trying to be like real pinball; there are mechanics and effects in this game that are impossible to do in reality. Like spaceships flying over the table or characters walking around shooting guns or getting involved in sword fights, the ball catching fire, multiball modes where gravity is reversed and the balls are levitating... you name it.The tables are well designed, though some more so than others. The tables that seem more fun to me are mostly the unlicensed ones, with Epic Quest, Secrets of the deep, Pasha, Tesla and Mars providing the best gameplay. Not that the rest is dull or anything, but after a while the 3D animations and character voices on the Star Wars and Marvel tables can get on your nerves. They overdid it on that department, and this sometimes overshadows the tables themselves. "Too much of a good thing."There's also an issue with input lag. Fortunately, it's not too big of a problem once you change your driver settings (setting "maximum pre-rendered frames" to 1 in the NVidia control panel). But even after configuring it that way, there's still a bit of input lag left. It doesn't make the game unplayable or anything, but it's still a minor annoyance. Unfortunately, the issue is being completely ignored by Zen Studios, even though people have repeatedly reported the problem on their forums. Hopefully Zen will change their attitude at some point (though I doubt it.)The only real downsides with this game though is the missing online multiplayer on PC (I think the console versions have that) and the price; nearly 100€ to get all tables is quite steep. I bought the game and a good selection of table packs when it came on Humble Bundle, and then more tables on Steam's Fall Sale. Otherwise it would simply be way too expensive. So if you downloaded the core game along with the Sorcerer's Lair table (those are for free, so just try it out) and you like what you see, it might be best to wait until the tables are on sale again.Bottom line: loads of fun, but why the heck isn't there online multiplayer on PC?

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												First, I want to say that this is not a pinball simulator. As far as I know, none of the tables are modeled from physical tables, and many of the effects, toys, and ball behavior would be difficult, if not impossible, to replicate on a physical machine. Also, the physics engine seems to be the first to suffer when the program is running slow, which can be annoying. All that being said, I really love these tables. Each feels very unique, but there's enough carried over from one design to the next that learning one helps improve your skill on many more of them. The graphics and characters are fun, the voice acting is usually quite good, and many of them have a surprisingly nice story flow. Having even just a few tables gives you a really nice set of choices. I have 33 tables, and I would say most feel completely unique from the others. The physics on some of the tables can be a bit wonky, but as long as the program is running well, the physics is consistant and I had no trouble getting used to the occasionally strange ball behavior.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												For a game whose sole mechanics could be summed up as "hit a ball with flippers to score points", Pinball FX2 absolutely shines with invention. Ball physics are generally top notch with only a couple of tables that love to see you fail (Civil War to name one); both the Marvel and Star Wars theme tables are spread across a wide sub-genre of characters, films, comics and cartoons; high score tables are implemented perfectly well, with notifications in-game to spur you on as you edge closer to a friend's score.It's pretty much the best Pinball game since Pinball Dreams - and while it may look like the developers are attempting to nickel and dime you with the amount of available packs, you'd be better off to pick them up one at a time and learn the tactics involved with each set. The 4-table packs can easily see you playing for 2 to 3 hours (per table) in order to truly appreciate where your high scores can be bettered, and there's rarely a dud table amongst them all.If you've the remotest interest or nostalgia for Pinball then do yourself a favour and pick up a pack or two, you won't regret it.

												This is the best pinball game I've played on the PC so far. Pinball FX2 offers a large variety of tables with plenty of action and lots of cool visual effects. All of the tables have lots of ramps and rails to shoot. I would say some of the tables are even overly busy which makes it difficult sometimes to see where you have to shoot the ball to complete objectives. The different camera angles help, but I don't like the close up camera angles because it reduces the overall field of view. The one major dislike for me is the lack of table friction. The Epic Quest table is my favorite providing some engaging monster slaying with a few RPG elements--a really great game complete with good music and voice.

content:
Posted: March 22
												As someone that played "Full Tilt" frequently, Pinball FX2 is a huge improvement.It's not so much a pinball game, as it is a ball physics simulator, that you can use on different tables.  The ball feels absolutely great as well(no innuendo intended).  It has good weight, and acts almost exactly as a pinball on an actual table would.  The flippers(for me at least) feel like the mechanical paddles on the few tables I frequent(LotR, Avatar, Terminator), and have a slight travel time that provides the illusion that there is some mechanism between my keystroke and the motion onscreen.  That's not to say they are delayed at all, they just have a touch of weight and travel that adds to the authenticity(note that some people have some kind of flipper lag bug, look into that before making the decision to purchase any dlc).The included table is actually wonderful.  The setting is a little cringy(a sort of goosebumps style horror theme), but the design of the table is fantastic.  It's got great visibility, a huge variety of different obstacles and targets, and a few really inventive quests to complete, my favorite of which being a mission where portals block all of the ramps, redirecting the ball until you summon a ghost which helps you destroy them(I'm aware it sounds moronic, but it really is good fun if you've got an accurate shot!).  The 3d models that flesh out the space are used very subtly as well, and do a great job of adding to the atmosphere, while not making the table seem inauthentic or impossible.  It's a table I'll deffinately be frequenting for a while to come.The free offering of this game is, I think, a phenominal value, and I highly suggest you give it a try as well.  I've purchased some additional tables, and will be reviewing them on their respective pages.If you love pinball(and don't have whatever flipper troubles that seem to be semi-common), and have a few hours to kill, I can't reccomend the free offering of Pinball FX2 enough!

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Well I really like this game.. what else can I say! Everything is pretty simple to follow and you do have a few options you can do with the settings although a couple of the controller ones might need a bit of work. Of course you can change the keys if you use a keyboard and there is a number of display and audio options. The restriction there is that the game is full screen - no windowed mode. It does have an orientation setting so you can even flip the game to portrait (90deg)- I was even stupid enough to try this and play it, now that was weird, but fun! I even toyed with trying to flip my monitor on my desk to match. Sheesh I mist be pitiful ;-)The game itself is great, everything any pinball lover would want and it comes installed free of charge with 1 fully working pinball table, and it's no cheap table either - it's one of the better ones. Speaking of tables, well I haven't got them all yet and I guess thats the beauty of this system. You can try any of the available tables first in the game, it gives you a fairly brief period of time to play, just enough to get an idea of the table, then if you like it you can go buy it as DLC. Some tables are sold separately and there are also table packs (3 or 4 tables in the pack) which works out slightly cheaper.My favourite table so far is Ms Splosion Man, it's kinda crazy - a bit like me I suspect. I have the 2nd highest score amongst my pinball friends on it - yet another thing about the game, you can add your friends or others with Pinball FX2 and see their scores in your game. That gives a bit of motivation to try and beat them. leaderboards, Wizard Scores and apparently tournaments - but I've not participated in one of those yet.Most of the tables can be a bit daunting the first time you play, especially if you are like me and don't bother reading anything and just jump in and play. Thankfully however, there are guides for every table within the game, you can actually pause out and read what you are supposed to be doing during the game if you like. The guides are pretty good overall, they give you enough info on the various things you can do in a table without making you have to read forever. Fairly well set out as well.Definitely worth the free download price and even more so worth spending money on for more tables to play. Get it!

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												One thing about the game is that it feels more organic.  In most pinball games, the game feels like it in entirely on rails, not just the visible ones placed on the table.  Once you learned how these rails work, earning large scores becomes an easy task.That rail feeling is not a problem in this game.  The way that the ball moves, it feels more organic.  While where the ball is when you use the flippers is important, ball speed and bounciness are also a factor.  This makes that a shot that worked the first time will not necessarily work again the next time.  Having the ball move as it does in real life, it means that ball control is much more important in order to succeed.The biggest draw about the game is seeing everything moving around on the boards.  Most modern pinball games have things that move around as things happen.  However, these movements are always simple that you can see even before the game start.  Once you trigger that movement, seeing it happen again is interesting only if it builds your score.What makes the game unique among most pinball games is that game table feels alive.  As you trigger certain targets, things will happen that would never happen in a normal pinball game.  In Earth Defense, a giant robot is trying to attack you.  If its lasers connect, it will cause your ball to change direction.  In The Empire Strikes Back, Darth Vader will use his force powers to block and even destroy your ball if you get close to him.  Even in Infinity Gauntlet, Thanos will alter the gameplay by swapping the controls and even turning the table upside down.  With all the special movements that can happen, it makes it worth it to experience the special moments of each table.Adding to the uniqueness are the games within the games.  Most pinball games will try to add more by simply using the scoreboard in order to play a bad video minigame.  Working with the video game format, these tables hold more than any physical table can hold.  In Moon Knight, he will use the ball as ammo to fire as hiding villains.  Tesla's table has a smaller table where you try to enter a goal using electro flippers.  In Paranormal, the ball can enter a higher second table in the attic in order to search for ghosts.  In what has to be the collection's highlight, in Star Wars: Starfighter Assault, you will go outside the table completely to shoot TIE fighter in what looks like the old-school game Galaga.  Knowing that there is more in store, spending additional time to explore them completely is a necessity.The one sticking point with the game is the price.  They give everybody one table, Sorcerer’s Lair, as a free table.  For all the rest, you have to pay for them separately.  With individual tables costing three dollars and a pack costing 10, it can get expensive to buy the full game.  If you want the full package, it is necessary to pay over 100 dollars.  At that price, the best way to get them all is to try to get them through a bundle.  Without a bundle, you need to make sure you try each table before buying.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A treasure of the oldest school of arcade gaming with modern video game touches. The tables are deep, with a variety of skill levels and styles represented. The physics are consistent and fun, providing fast paced action with all of the nuance and subtlety of the real thing, even if it is not an exact and realistic simulation. You will have to master tricky flipper work and timely table nudges along with knowledge of the table and twitch reflexes. Finish this off with lavishly produced themes and thoughtfully evocative table design and you have a real classic.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2013
												Finally! Not since Pinball Dreams/Fantasies have I played a pinball game this polished and this enjoyable. The key that makes this stand out, in my view, is the viewing angle & dynamic camera work along with the precise 'feeling of control' you can achieve with the ball. Most pinball games just don't get it right!It doesn't have simulator accuracy but it is so fun! This does have an advantage as there are unique things on many tables you simply cannot do with a conventional 'real' pinball table design.Tables all come alive with beautiful sound, animations & mini-games; the Star Wars tables have to be my favs!  Price of the tables is a little high when you add them all up, but you do get quality and all have great replayablity. Achievements are hard to get!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												I just recently started playing this game thanks to my boyfriend, and while I can't exactly say that I'm a fan of pinball, this game is actually a lot of fun. I've never played on a real pinball machine, so I can't compare this to the real thing. The game itself is free and comes with one table, but there are a lot of other ones available for purchase, and they seem to be making new ones every now and then. Most of the tables look very nice and are very well-made. I was lucky enough to get ahold of quite a few tables through Humble Bundle at a great price, as well as one or two on sale on Steam, and at those prices it's worth it even if you might not be a hardcore pinball fan. Some tables are more difficult to get high scores on than others, and every table has two achievements, so there's always a challenge waiting. My personal favourite is the Darth Vader table (both because I'm a fan of him, and because it's one of the few tables I'm decent at), but all the Star Wars tables are great in my opinion. So, in short: Fun game. :)

												All round excellent pinball game, good physics engine and a nice variety of tables. Graphically very slick also. Highly recommended tables would include 'Plants vs Zombies', 'Ms Splosion man' (don't let the pink put ya off), and 'Quest for epic loot' (hope I got the name of that one right). number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												Did you grow up playing the default pinball game on windows? Think of this as effectively the same thing - it's a good time-passer, looks nice, plays well, and generally I've found a few tables that I've had a blast playing.Some tables are, as would be expected, hit or miss with some people. I've played some that I've frankly disliked and continued to dislike from the instant I started playing them, and other that just clicked.So far, I've found that the game is solid, and if you're looking to have fun, picking it up on sale is not a bad idea. I would personally recommend Paranormal, Earth Defense and Secrets of the Deep (being the three tables I've played primarily).Hardcore pinball players or fans of the real deal might not be 100% satisfied with this, as it has obvious physics flaws that some veterans will pick up on rather quickly, especially regarding momentum and velocity of the ball, so keep this in mind.All in all, if you see this on sale and are asking yourself if you want to buy a table or two, consider this:Do you enjoy pinball? Consider it.Do you value realism? Rethink whether you actually want this game or not. Tables tend to lean more on the fantastic side.Do you want a timesink or something that you can pick up and put down quickly? It's pretty fast to boot and close and tables are up and running PDQ. The load times are not that bad.Overall, a great fantasy pinball game, and plenty of fun to be had, but if you're looking to play realistic pinball, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												When I was younger I use to play a game called Extreme Pinball.  It was an awesome game, and I've spent years trying to find a game to rival it.  Pinball FX2 (also known as Zen Pinball?)  definitely steps up to the plate.  The game gets some flack for not having realistic tables, but that doesn't mean they aren't awesome fun!  If you have some friends playing, competing for high score is also very addictive.They give you one of their best tables for free, and sell additional tables for relatively low prices, especially if you grab them on sale.  If you remember the good old days of arcades filled with pinball machines or are just fascinated by the idea there is very little reason not to give this game a shot.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Their are only 2 pinball games that are worth ANY time, Pinball FX2 being one of them. When this first hit the xbox platform I finally found a reason to play xbox, well, other than the Forza series. Though, I probably even still spent more time in Pinball FX2. And now being on PC, I get to spend all my PC time (well, iMac time. Yes, it plays perfect on iMac too via CrossOver) again with my first true love, pinball. Of all the fantastic tables available, I think still to this day Secrets of the Deep in the FX2 core pack is still a huge favorite of mine. The crazy multi-ball on this table is just like awesome, and the music also helps take you from the real world and into pinball world. Yes, their really is a pinball world, though if you do EVER make it their, you will NEVER want to leave :)…  Each table has loads of variety and will keep you entertained for many many hours. If you even think you could love pinball, of even if you don’t, you owe it to yourself to try this. The FREE table it does come with, Sorcerer’s Lair was just one of the ones I purchased on xbox due to the fact its also a really good table. If I had to pick 1 issue with Pinball FX2, other than not being a native mac port, it would have to be I was really disappointed to not see the weekly leaderboard scores. But hey, it just means more hours to get the really big score to hit the top ten all-time leaderboards after all. Sorry, have to leave now to go find an opening to pinball world.. See you their……. If you make it...

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Their are only 2 pinball games that are worth ANY time, Pinball FX2 being one of them. When this first hit the xbox platform I finally found a reason to play xbox, well, other than the Forza series. Though, I probably even still spent more time in Pinball FX2. And now being on PC, I get to spend all my PC time (well, iMac time. Yes, it plays perfect on iMac too via CrossOver) again with my first true love, pinball. Of all the fantastic tables available, I think still to this day Secrets of the Deep in the FX2 core pack is still a huge favorite of mine. The crazy multi-ball on this table is just like awesome, and the music also helps take you from the real world and into pinball world. Yes, their really is a pinball world, though if you do EVER make it their, you will NEVER want to leave :)…  Each table has loads of variety and will keep you entertained for many many hours. If you even think you could love pinball, of even if you don’t, you owe it to yourself to try this. The FREE table it does come with, Sorcerer’s Lair was just one of the ones I purchased on xbox due to the fact its also a really good table. If I had to pick 1 issue with Pinball FX2, other than not being a native mac port, it would have to be I was really disappointed to not see the weekly leaderboard scores. But hey, it just means more hours to get the really big score to hit the top ten all-time leaderboards after all. Sorry, have to leave now to go find an opening to pinball world.. See you their……. If you make it...

content:
Posted: March 3
												Pinball FX2 Review - Raymond KTLet me make this abundantly clear, Pinball FX 2 is definitely a PC game that should be experienced by all gamers out there, from the hard-core pinball fanatic to the casual pinball player alike. Pinball FX2 is the best, I said the best pinball game *(virtually) that I’ve ever played! The game is free to play with one table included. You can try the other tables out for a limited score. You can buy the other tables individually or as bundles. I just bought most of the tables from a humble bundle deal where you pay what you want. Those complaining about micro-transactions have no ground to stand on because the game is free to play. Even for a relative pinball novice like me, Pinball FX2 has a lot to offer. The feel of real pinball is here, in a game that takes full advantage of its freedom from physical restraints.Pinball FX 2 isn't a game so much as it's a platform on which to purchase, download, and play games. The games in question are different pinball tables, and at launch there are no fewer than 13 of them available. It's a good selection, and what all of the tables have in common is that they look and sound great, they behave realistically, and they get a little better every time another of your friends shows up on the robust leaderboard system. Pinball FX 2 is free to download, while tables are reasonably priced at 800 points for packs of four and 200 points each for those that are available to purchase individually. If you enjoy pinball, downloading Pinball FX 2 is a no-brainer. – Game spotYou certainly don't need to be a pinball wizard to have fun with Pinball FX 2, or even to rack up some respectable scores. Some of the tables are quite challenging, though, and a couple of them can be frustrating if you have trouble making specific shots that they demand of you. On the flip side, other tables are easy enough that you can score millions and hit plenty of cool-looking rails without having to try too hard.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Pinball FX2 is an involved, high-level game that requires your complete and undivided focus. It does not take much to play on a casual level, but for the driven and determined it is only the tip of the iceberg. In order to prove your worth in the FX2 leagues, you must provide every single ounce of your skill, awareness, flipper precision, and table bumping mastery to even begin on the lower levels of the ladder system. From there is a grueling journey upwards to being the very best at pinball. Perhaps, if you are enough of a video game master, you will able to top the high score of the Pinball Wizard for the ultimate in Pinball FX2 prestige. Pinball FX2, it's okay.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Graphics/Design - 8.0Sound - 7.5Gameplay - 9.5Value - 9.5Single Player Playtime - N/AOverall 8.7Here's a game I've spent a lot of time with.  The graphics are what you'd expect from a game where you only see a pinball table most of the time and the graphical options are minimal.  However, the great detail put into the tables and into the various minigames are where the game really makes it's mark in quality.  With all the crazy elements the average map has going on while you're playing, this obviously isn't a game trying to replicate an authentic pinball experience and Zen Studios uses this to their full advantage.  On Star Wars tables you might have X-Wings and Tie Fighters shooting at each other or anti-aircraft guns shooting at them.  You might see Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker fighting or Boba Fett in action.  Whether it's Star Wars, Marvel characters or any of the other tables, the table design, mini games and action on the sides have all been crafted to fit in with the reality of each tables fictional (or in some cases real life) universe.  There's nearly 50 maps out currently and you will find a dud here and there if you played every map but the number of high quality fun maps available is awesome.  The sound is decent, nothing particulary stands out there.  Considering how long you can last on some of the maps, it's the perfect game to listen to your own music while you play.  Some of the maps can feel cheap at times.  When you hit a seemingly good shot then it goes in one of the side gutters without giving you a chance to stop it, it can feel cheap.  You always want to feel like the reason you lost is because of a mistake you made, not because the table is designed to be very unforgiving to shots at certain angles.  The value someone can get out of this game is endless really.  There's enough maps out there to last hundreds of hours and hundreds more hours spent to truly master them all.  It's a great game with maps and patches that are still being put out for it.  Highly Recommended.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I played this game VERY extensively on the Xbox 360 and loved it -- in fact, I have purchased every table.  I recently built an arcade cabinet (with flipper buttons on the sides) and figured Pinball FX2 would be wonderful on it.  Sadly, the flipper lag is just enough to take you out of the pinball experience.  Try playing "Future Pinball" and you'll see what I mean.  When flippers in a pinball game are responsive, you forget that you're not playing on a real pinball table.Edit: After doing some research, I discovered that by disabling VSYNC and setting my pre-rendered frames to 1 (both done in the Nvidea control panel), the flippers became perfectly responsive.  As such, I can recommend this game without hesitation.My only hope now is for a nice sale on the tables.  I don't really want to re-purchase $100 worth of tables I've already bought on my 360.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Great game. It's "Free to Play," but only comes with one starter table, "The Sorceror's Lair." The free table, however, is one of my favorites. Additional tables are reasonably priced. Most of them are really enjoyable. If you're just looking for something to kill 20-30 minutes of time, you can hit up a few tables, and have some casual gaming fun. If you're a huge pinball fan, you'll probably love this game. The tables have a variety of objectives for those who have the skill to achieve them. If you hate pinball, you'll probably hate this. I sometimes find it frustrating in the same way I find a physical pinball machine to be frustrating. I am horrible at pinball. It shows every time I play this game, yet I've already logged 6 hours into this and keep purchasing new tables to try out. I couldn't play this for hours at a time, but for small doses when I don't have the attention span for story-based games, this is one of my top choices to play.The animations and voiceovers are interesting and there are 8 different table views, which is a great feature. If you don't like the camera angle on a table, you can easily swap it to another at any time with the touch of a button. You can tweak your settings, too, if you don't mind giving up the leaderboards. When I really like a table, I will sometimes increase my ball count to 10 just to keep playing the same table and see how high I can get my score.
