content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												The two biggest video pinball games on Steam are Pinball Arcade and this game. Both have similar revenue models (free with paid tables) and both offer dynamic viewpoints for optimal play. But while Pinball Arcade's legacy tables are nice, I would have to say Pinball FX2 is a superior product. It's not just the Marvel and Star Wars licensed tables (though they certainly help) but I feel Pinball FX2 definitely takes advantage of the fact that it is a video game and therefore its tables can do things that are incredibly difficult if not impossible on a real table (including mechanics and animated models) while still keeping realistic pinball physics. Pinball FX2 does not insult customers by offering "professional" versions of tables. All tables feature operator menus and certain tables feature special balls (The Avengers table in fact makes it a gameplay mechanic). Besides Star Wars and Marvel, Pinball FX2 offers many tables that are a joy to play and very engaging. The Super League Football table in particular has become a table I am incredibly fond of. And lest not forget there is a free table in the form of Sorcerer’s Lair which is nothing to sneeze at. It's just as fun and of good quality as any of the paid tables.For me, personally apart from the quality of the product, one of the biggest draws that encourages me to keep playing is the native integration with Steamworks so that all of your friends' high scores for any give table are automatically displayed in game. Thus it becomes a game in itself to see if you can best your friends' high scores.Overall this is a wonderful product if you enjoy pinball. I don't want to say its "better" than Pinball Arcade due to the different roles they fill, but it definitely has a much better pricing model. Must play.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Absolutely stunning graphics, fabulous physics and challenging design makes the Pinball FX2 series a must-have for arcade pinball enthusiasts.  I have purchased all the tables with the exception of the new Dr. Strange, and played all a number of times.   I must say, the diversity of challenges and overall feel of the different tables is truly incredible.  Some flipper and ball action is lightning fast on newer tables, while others are true to their original old-school roots; those found in the Zen Classics Pack play slower and more subdued; you can almost feel the bulk of the flippers, with less flashy play and heavier movement.  Be it the 3D environments of the Star Wars or Marvel tables, the minimalism of V12, El Dorado or Mars, the flash of Ms. Splosion or the charm of Epic Quest and Earth Defense, there is something for everyone here.   IMHO, V12 and Tesla are the hardest to score points on; V12 has a rather brutal left lane gap that is an unholy drain of the worst order.  But for either a quick pick-up game or lengthy marathon, you can't go wrong with this re-imagining of an arcade staple.  You have your choice of 360 controller support (which is quite responsive) or keyboard bashing.  And the community score leaders and Pinball Wizard status allows you to not only challenge friends, but challenge yourself to reach the pinnacle of others playing a particular table.  Superb overview of achievements and table layouts compliment your quest, and you will find yourself unlocking new challenges at every turn. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												TL;DR: Feels great because the sound design is amazing, the controls are snappy and the ball physics are spot on. Comes free with one good table but all others cost money (about £2 for single tables, £7 for the bundles). Has well integrated worldwide and friends leaderboards to extend that further. Overall, outstanding - controller recommended.Full:It's good at introducing new players:This game really is something special. The tables all come with guides telling you what to do, you can choose between camera angles until you get something that feels comfortable and you can pan your camera around the table at any point to see what joins to what and where everything is making it an excellent game for newcomers like myself. There are even options to change different things about each table to make the game easier or harder as you see fit (though that does disqualify the results of altered games from the leaderboards).It feels really good:The balls handle really well (hehehe) and feel really realistic (hehehe) and feels really awesome if you use an Xbox controller (With the triggers acting as the flippers - which is the default control scheme) which the game can detect quickly without having to restart. This is down - I think - to how responsive the controls are and the really good sound design assisted by the care put into making almost everything seem like it's actually part of a physical pinball table.The pricing is surprisingly fair:All this on top of the game itself being free. It only comes with one table to begin with but it's a fun table which shows off all the crazy things the tables can do (Minigames away from the table, minigames on the table, animatronic things, etc.) as well as showing off just how responsive the game feels. All the other tables do cost but the prices are low (<£3 for each table, £7 for bundles of 4) and I've found that each can keep me engaged for large swathes of time - even more so when switching between them.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												This is a review for the Star Wars: Balance of the Force PackThough I’m not a huge Star Wars fan, the films and games have always been a part of my life, and I’ve always appreciated them in the same way one might appreciate anything good, like ice cream, or water slides. These pinball tables, created by Zen Studios, make the best use of the Star Wars license that I’ve ever seen. The touch and feel, the music, the sounds, the reproduced dialogue spoken by sound-alike voice actors, everything is on point. I’m surprised that more people on my friends list don’t play this.Pinball FX 2 has quite a few incredible Star Wars themed tables, but I wanted to highlight this pack, because I feel it is among the best. The Star Wars, Episode VI: Return of the Jedi Table draws out all of the best scenes from the films, had incredible character models, awesome game modes, and multi-ball. There is a speeder bike mini-game which is a blast. The Darth Vader Tribute table brings together scenes from all the films, beginning with an optimal story mode of Vader’s assembly and the infamous “No!” The table is really well-designed and polished, and has a trench battle mini-game where you finally get to play as one of cinema’s greatest villains. Last but not least, the Starfighter Assault table is an astonishing achievement. I can imagine someone trying to create a dual pinball table and failing miserably, but here it works so well. It gives me nostalgia for long afternoons spent playing X-wing on the PC as a teen. You can choose to align with the Empire or the Rebels, and each mode is different enough to make it worth it to play again with the opposing faction. These tables should be in your library, even if you aren’t the biggest Star Wars fan.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												It's been a long time since I've seen a really good pinball video game.  Pinball FX2 pushes all the right buttons, bringing me back to when I used to play Epic Pinball on my 486 machine 20 years ago.  It fully supports both keyboard and gamepad control and both work very well.  My only gripe with controls is that manual control over the plunger is very difficult to use and only seems to utilize less than half of a thumbstick's range.The main strength of this game is the table design.  Since all the tables are original, they aren't constrained by the laws of physics or physical design limitations like real tables are.  It allows the tables to all have their own unique feel and utilize game mechanics that are only possible here.  Unfortunately this brings with it some wonky ball physics in some places, mostly from balls rolling back down ramps though I believe this was done on purpose to avoid straight gutter balls.The game utilizes global and friend leaderboards as well as having 2 achievements per table to add to replayability.  It's great fun beating your friends' scores and hunting down the achievements, some of which are extremely difficult.On the downside, some of the tables have some minor performance problems such as stuttering when transitioning between the main table and a sub-table for a minigame.  Some people also experience input lag though I believe it is pretty rare.  Overall, the graphics are fantastic and it runs very smoothly so it's easy to ignore the sporadic problems.  A bigger issue for me is that the character banter on some of the tables (especially the licensed ones) can get quite tiring.  There does not seem to be any way to disable it without turning off the sound completely.Some people may also be put off by having to buy tables separately.  They come in packs of 3-4 for $10 or single tables for $3 which seems pretty reasonable to me.  On sale, it's a bargain.  In addition, you can demo any table for a couple minutes before you buy to see if you like it before spending any money.  The game also has one free table that everyone can enjoy.If you like pinball, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I tried this initially as a curiosity, and now own all tables, and buy any new ones as they come out. This from a guy who's Father bought a Pinball Machine back in the day, had it at home. It truly brings Pinball into the computer age in stunningly impressive fashion, takes it to the next level and beyond. There isn't just scoring opportunity, there are layers, and many of them, and throught time you find the secrets to higher scoring, you can compete with friends or with the world, there's even Guides for the specific games, and beyond that it enhances fans of Marvel Comics, or Star Wars, and the latest one (as of this writing) with Soccer is an absolute blast, and I know nothing about soccer. Pinball FX2 is a gift that keeps on giving. Their most major competition, 'Pinball Arcade' is also good, and as they bring old school machines into your Steam, Pinball FX2 is the new school, and even ahead of its time. You simply can't go wrong with either, but this one dazzles...and dazzles layer by layer of accomplishments, scoring, competion, graphics and the one word to describe it all...FUN. Absolutely worth it.

												The best Pinball simulator on the PC, oh wait it's not really a simulator it add's special effect's so its even better to play !The table's are well designed with plenty of mini games to discover without getting bored easy. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												Pinball FX2 is definantly an interesting game on steam that has the label of being free, with that said only one of the countless tables, the sorcerers lair, is actually free, the the rest must be purchased with an average of about $2 per tableWith that being said I personnally think this is great, the way I see it for one play on a real pinball table is about 50 cents, so if you play one table that you buy at least 4 times you have got your moneys worth, the rest is essentially BonusNow on to the gameplay, the tables are complicated and despite each one having a guide you will just have to play them to learn them which I think is part of the fun, especially when you learn how to hit jackpots consistantly, you control the flippers, and can even shake the table as if it were a real machine, and it will warn you not to do itThe only real complaint I have for the gameplay is that with a real pinball machine if you hit the flipper button harder it will flip harder, however you can't really emulate that on a keyboard, this isn't necesarrily the games fault it just is a problemNow as far as the tables go, I personnally have played almost all of them across all platforms, and will say they are for the most part great across the board, there are some exceptions like Deadpool table and Civil War table which seem too random, which is a shame because I love the source materialThe tables are all unique they are not just cosmetically different from each other and each has thier own set of objectives and goals, most even have minigames to be played which is a nice change of pace sometimesOverall I would say that Pinball FX2 is the best way of playing pinball out there short of going to an arcade and playing real pinball tables, do not let the appearance of pay to play stop you from buying a table, because you will definintly get your moneys worth

There are even options to change different things about each table to make the game easier or harder as you see fit (though that does disqualify the results of altered games from the leaderboards).It feels really good:The balls handle really well (hehehe) and feel really realistic (hehehe) and feels really awesome if you use an Xbox controller (With the triggers acting as the flippers - which is the default control scheme) which the game can detect quickly without having to restart. This is down - I think - to how responsive the controls are and the really good sound design assisted by the care put into making almost everything seem like it's actually part of a physical pinball table.The pricing is surprisingly fair:All this on top of the game itself being free. It only comes with one table to begin with but it's a fun table which shows off all the crazy things the tables can do (Minigames away from the table, minigames on the table, animatronic things, etc.) as well as showing off just how responsive the game feels. All the other tables do cost but the prices are low (<£3 for each table, £7 for bundles of 4) and I've found that each can keep me engaged for large swathes of time - even more so when switching between them.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												Pinball FX2 Review - Raymond KTLet me make this abundantly clear, Pinball FX 2 is definitely a PC game that should be experienced by all gamers out there, from the hard-core pinball fanatic to the casual pinball player alike. Pinball FX2 is the best, I said the best pinball game *(virtually) that I’ve ever played! The game is free to play with one table included. You can try the other tables out for a limited score. You can buy the other tables individually or as bundles. I just bought most of the tables from a humble bundle deal where you pay what you want. Those complaining about micro-transactions have no ground to stand on because the game is free to play. Even for a relative pinball novice like me, Pinball FX2 has a lot to offer. The feel of real pinball is here, in a game that takes full advantage of its freedom from physical restraints.Pinball FX 2 isn't a game so much as it's a platform on which to purchase, download, and play games. The games in question are different pinball tables, and at launch there are no fewer than 13 of them available. It's a good selection, and what all of the tables have in common is that they look and sound great, they behave realistically, and they get a little better every time another of your friends shows up on the robust leaderboard system. Pinball FX 2 is free to download, while tables are reasonably priced at 800 points for packs of four and 200 points each for those that are available to purchase individually. If you enjoy pinball, downloading Pinball FX 2 is a no-brainer. – Game spotYou certainly don't need to be a pinball wizard to have fun with Pinball FX 2, or even to rack up some respectable scores. Some of the tables are quite challenging, though, and a couple of them can be frustrating if you have trouble making specific shots that they demand of you. On the flip side, other tables are easy enough that you can score millions and hit plenty of cool-looking rails without having to try too hard.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												There are two kinds of video pinball games in the world: the kind that try to be an extremely authentic simulation of a physical machine, and the kind that throw in some elements that would be impossible or impractical in reality (creatures wandering the playfield, etc.). If you want pure physical simulation, go find Pinball Arcade. But Pinball FX2 is a good-to-great collection of tables with mild to moderate levels of "video-ness."

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I simply am not aware of a better pinball simulator.  Zen Studios has made a very solid-playing pinball game, and has the best licensing to boot.  Sure, it's a bit of a downer that you can't unlock more tables without paying for them, as the number of free tables you get to start with is pretty small.  However, the tables are of very high production quality, and CAN be had for relatively cheap if you're patient enough to wait for them to go on sale.  Either way, the value is there.The replay value speaks for itself, and while you may eventually reach your limit for how much pinball you can handle in one sitting, with them CONSTANTLY adding new content you'll likely never get bored of playing Pinball FX2.  If you can, hook this up to your big sceen tv at your next party.  I guarantee it will be a hit.Now if only they would go and get the rights to and do remakes of all those old Bally-Midway pinball games from the 70's 80's and 90's...

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Pinball FX 2 offers over 50 tables, which is huge! Most are good tables where the physics of the ball is very realistic with the rest of the board. The sound is also very nice. There are often plenty of missions per tray to do and it is often fun and enjoyable to play. PFX2 does not have too many bugs (but I have discovered some of them all the same). Graphically it's very beautiful too. It just lacks the ability to compete online tournaments with players from around the world. This is the big black point of the game if I had to give one (because finding everything perfect would be amazing anyway). However this is a very good game of pinball that I recommend. And then 3 € per table can seem a lot if you want them all, but do not forget that it's only 3 € where with a real pinball machine it was about 1 € per game! So buy Pinball FX 2!

number of helpful: 22 of 45 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												I think it's about time to share a few words about this game with people that might be looking for a reason to give this a try.Well I certainly hope that you know what pinball is. Even if you never came in contact with the real thing you probably played the old pinball on Windows XP or at least heard about it right? No? WELL WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING HERE THAN? Real pinball works on a basic principle. You throw in a quarter and it usually gives you 3 balls to play with.You are trying to not let the ball drain with your flippers while getting a score for anything you do. Once all your balls are lost, the game ends and you take place on the leaderboards. Sounds simple and it can be, depends how you look at it and what table are you playing.Which brings us to this electronic pinball game. It's not going to ask you for quarters to play! In fact, it's like you have your own pinball machine at home where you just push start and you are given free balls to play with. But this thing is not going to cost you hundreds up to thousands of dollars and it's not going to take up a big space. This game will only take up space on your HDD and each table will cost you 2.99€ or your regional equivalent.There's one free table for you to play with and every other table you can just try for free. The free table in question is Sorcerer's Lair and it's alot of fun! You'll find many hours of enjoyement on this free table alone and it will give you a good idea about how the game works and if it suits you.The physics are very real, if it could be any closer to its real counterpart, it would be just scary. The speed might seem to be a bit too high but there are many realy tables that are even faster. This is still very fair but will make damn sure to test your fast hands out. Your ball can drain without you knowing what just happened, but that's the way it is. As you play more and more, you will eventually get better too.If you are by a chance a fan of MARVEL or Star Wars, you are going to be happy as there are many tables in these themes. At the time of writing this there are 2 South Park tables, a Walking Dead table (based on the first game by telltale games), a plants vs. zombies table and many original design tables for you to choose from. Some are easy, some are hard, some are not worth getting as much as the others. But they are all quality products and you can really see that alot of hard work went into all of them. And as I said, you can "try before you buy" so you won't have to blindly buy into things you might not like in the end.The community is really friendly and if you find yourself playing pinball FX2 alot, you might want to go check out an amazing steam group by the name of "Pinball Family" and ask for an invite. We are competing there each week on a different table, players of all skills!All in all: if you are looking for a quallity electronic pinball, don't look any further, you found it! It's not going to cost you a fortune to play any table you'd like. The tables behave like the real thing and are filled with eye candy in form of 3D models that you wouldn't find on real tables... At least for now, once holograms are going to be a normal daily thing, you might find some 3D animated models in real pinball tables.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												A kids game. Avoid.Nowhere close to a real pinball experience. A game(not a simulation) in every sense of the word. Anyone who has played a real machine and expects the same from this "game" will be disappointed. From poor flipper response and unrealistic physics this is just about selling DLC in the form of tables. If the tables were true thats one thing but its just a merchandising effort, plain and simple.I'm guessing the reviewers have never grown up playing actual pinball tables and the reviews show it.Play the free tables, see how poorly the flippers react and the general physics are then spend a few hundred and buy your own table. I did and i'd rather play one real table than spend the same amount playing 50 awful tables with average physics and no soul.Saving your game also ruins the experience of an already sold out game. Save your cash.

												This is a brilliant collection of 23  pinball tables  sold in six  separate packs (the Star Wars pack  has 3, the rest four tables each).  These are the  most beautiful tables I've ever played.  They almost feel like playing on a real table, the graphics are so good.  You can compare your high scores for each table with your friends, and  the accumulated high scores for each table   also place you on a separate   score table.Ball physics is as good as it gets.  I do feel some of the tables lack the ability  to play skill shots,  they re more  about lucky than anything, but other tables compensate for  that.  If you like pinball games I recommend you don't wait till the sales and get them now.  I thought at first   the  full cost was prohibitive, but when you consider you are getting 23 tables,  it's actually a steal as each table works out at less than £1.40 each (approx $2)

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I love Pinball FX2. It's the best pinball game I have ever played and most tables fall somewhere between "really good" and "awesome" for me. I like that you can purchase only the tables you want (one of the only games in existence, where I think the DLC model makes a lot of sense). So if you are a fan of for example Star Wars, get one or two of the packs and have HOURS of fun with the tables. You like South Park? Get the two South Park tables... Honestly if you like the subject of a table you can hardly go wrong. And even tables based on stuff I didn't know before or didn't care for are almost all really enjoyable.The only issue I had with it was the very long play times that could be achieved with reliable bang backs, that not only made the game a touch too hard, but were also required to master, if you wanted to have higher scores. But they changed that and now I am enjoying it just a touch more than before. ^^So if you have only the faintest interest in video game pinball (and/or have played classics like Pro Pinball - Timeshock) do yourself a favor: stop reading here and try it.For the rest, that want my opinion on why the latest reviews seem so negative read on:The above mentioned "Bang-Back-Issue" is apparently a great source of anger in the forums and I don't really understand why it has to necessarily affect reviews of the game. I have watched a great deal of videos to get better at the game, but on some tables in particular it just seemed that the best score is achieved with a lot of dexterity playing the same shots over and over, while essentially having unlimited playtime, due to being able to really 100% bang back the ball. I didn't mind too much, since I personally could not do it all of the time so my playtime was in fact limited, but on the other hand did I not have any ambition to play for global high scores and when my friends lost intrest there was nobody to realistically beat anymore. xD I feel with the new changes and a bit of practice it would not be out of the question to reach maybe some High Scores (but time will tell ;P)Haven't heard of the unfair EULA thing that seems to be discussed here. It might be important to know and maybe it's not the best practice to change it after such a long time, but on the other hand they almost certainly reserved the right to change it and it doesn't change the fact, that the game is excellent. I just despise people playing something for like 500 hours and then "changing their opinion" to "not recommended"... New technical issues arrising or the game suddenly not working on the newest Windows 11 I could understand.Also: get off your high horses with the developer "not listening to the community". First of all, I am pretty sure they do read a lot of the stuff that gets posted, second: just because YOU think an issue is present doesn't mean everybody else would be okay with the change or lack thereof (regarding the nudge debate). In the end it is the developers choice and if they want to reset the High Scores and change some internals, then they are going to do it. PERIODYou have the choice to not buy future tables and just enjoy everything you have purchased thus far.

												Just simply the best video pinball game I have ever played. But what is even better are the DLC tables. The tables are original and well designed and just great fun to play. I am terrible at both real and video pinball, but it really doesn't matter, the games are just good fun. I must have played over 30 real pinball tables at Play Expo Manchester 2015 and I didn't really enjoy playing a lot of them. The ball speed and flipper response just didn't feel smooth and natural, I can't explain why.  Or the tables seemed boring. Great art but no substance. Playing this game with the xbox controller feels great, very natural and responsive. And the tables designs are just really up there with the best of the real pinball tables. Fantastic art, lots of action and lots of depth if you are any good at pinball.If you like pinball at all, or have always wanted to try pinball, then this is the only one to download.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												The people who are complaingin about the EULA agreement have not read it.   There is nothing out of the ordinary compared to ANY other EULA argeement on any game they have purchased in the last 10 years.   These detractors are spreading  misinformation based on ignorance.Zen IS NOT, and COULD NOT "mine" your PC for "passwords" or your "e-mails" to gather information about your friends or proclivities.  That's an absurd claim without basis along with any "malware" accusations.   I'm sure every one of these people carry an Apple or Android controlled phone that DOES do these things, yet they are happy to comply. Nothing in the Zen agreement comes even close to these claims.    Zen's EULA pertains to ONLY the information about the use of the game off and online as well as any info you have chosen to share with them pertaining your account at Zen ( i.e., high scores or messages sent to other users using their service)   If you have not told them, or sent a message through their service, about the only thing they can know about you are the licenses you own and how long you've played each table and what your scores are.    Anyone claiming otherwise has not actually READ the agreement - or probably any other EULA agreements.    If Highscore erasure from time to time is a complete dealbreaker, then I guess you have a claim to be mad.  Why not just buck up and play again to see how good you still are?   Most erasures are a result of cheating and the scores are cleared to make the charts fair to all those who don't play unfairly.  High scores aret commandments written in stone.It's a game, for crying out loud - in the 80's, sometimes the macine got unplugged and your high score got erased.  Oh well, we didn't go crying home to momma that my life accomplishment was erased from history.   For the price of a hamburger, you are getting a highly polished, physically realistic pinball simulation that is lightyears ahead of almost any other video pinball game ever made.  Keep things in perspective and enjoy it for what it is:  a tremedous amount of entertainment value, with a high production value, with great detail and crafted with great care -  for a pittance.

												The Venom table came out recently. Just got it tonight. It looks cool and it's challenging. It's another great table of MANY great tables that have come out this year.Hey developers!!!!!!! How about a Batman '66 table?-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This is BY FAR the best pinball game out there. The variety of tables is great. The other pinball game is very expensive....and, frankly, these tables feel modern. I like that. This is the game I always come back to. Maybe it's because it's playable and there's an opportunity to feel like you can get good at it. A lot of games seem impossible. Some people love that kind of challenge....getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off....throwing the controller across the room.....smashing the keyboard in frustration. I prefer to feel like I have a chance.....that there's a light at the end of the tunnel..and even if it's a train.....I can press "d" or "a", or shift left or right with my controller, and get out of the way. Too many games feel like they aren't very inviting to the casual player. This game isn't that at all. You can have fun.....and if you want to compete.....you can try to beat the best scores (Are those scores real? They seem a bit over the top to me)---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------edit:The Star Wars tables are mostly great, Spiderman table is glitchy for some reason.....the other Marvel tables are mostly cool. The newer ones are better. South Park Tables rock (didn't expect that). Deadpool is very hard (and the animations are a bit much). The Walking Dead table is GREAT.I can't really compain about much because this is the game I keep coming back to. I play a table or two almost every day ....just to wind down . -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------My ONE serious complaint is that you get no credit for buying these tables (on  at least one other platform?) You could get a game code you could use once. It seems fair to me.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												picked this up late 2014 in a humble bundle with lots of Star Wars and lots of Marvel tables, plus several others. was a big fan of pinball when i was young (early to late 80's) and remembered liking the one included with Windows forever ago. PROStables feel solid, very much realistic in their physics; can feel almost just as satisfying as any table i used to play IRL. i think they have done a good job balancing the fact that you can overcome physical limitations with keeping the play very much realistic in a physical sense, for the most part. the tables seem to cover most of the common pinball tropes that i recall; as well as having some devices of their own that can be seen to resonate through various parts of the collection.also, in general, i think they've done a good job of keeping the challenge level to a similar level you would find on real pinball tables; a few of the tables feel a bit overly-inclined to take you to the drain down the side slots, or to throw the ball in the dead center of the flippers; but most have a decently long 'grace period' in which the ball is auto-relaunched if you end up draining quickly after launch. also, the competitive part of the system is interesting; there are theoretically tournaments from time to time; but it's got good tracking of your ranking compared to your friends, with the stats being accessible easily, and a little trophy on the icon for each table for which you've got top score among your friends. the menu UI is fairly intuitive and i have no real complaints in that department; it's not terribly inspired, but it's not a PITA either.CONSthe flippers seem to only be available (i could have missed something somewhere) as "left flipper"/"right flipper" control mapping, which can be a real pain on a few of the tables where this means you're constantly banging the ball into a flipper that should be on a separate button, or on an inverted control scheme. (e.g. an upper set of flippers mapped backwards.) mostly, though, this hasn't been a huge issue, but it's definitely a constant annoyance, and it's one difference from most real pinball tables and also at least one other pinball game i've played, 'Pinball Arcade'. also, either the game or the tables seem to be poorly optimized; i get more frame-rate issues and the like on this than i do on the majority of immersive 3D games i play; and i have played another pinball title (Pinball Arcade, focused on emulating actual tables rather than creating new ones) which has no issues at all on my machine.  if you have such issues, you'll need to figure out how to enable triple buffering for your machine, which can be a hassle.still, well worth the effort IMO; but c'mon Zen! the game has been out there for a long time now, and IMO there's no reason at all not to be able to fix these problems; at least using the known solution that seems to fix the issues on most systems. why not just spend the few days/weeks of developer time to at least enable that much of a fix on the majority of the systems that having the issue rather than leaving your customers, some of whom are going to be far from technical, to have to find and implement what can be a quirky PITA solution? and for that matter, you ought to be optimizing this thing so it sings; it's very disappointing, after having seen what was perfectly acceptable performance for a pinball game way back—on a Pentium with a PCI video card—to be left with the feeling that the game is at least moderately sluggish in some cases. and, yes, i know it's more complex than that, but the point is that this really isn't rocket science here, guys, and optimizing the engine should have been a top priority.SUMMARYif you like pinball in one form or another, and especially if you like the themes of the tables offered, this is a good game to have; for the number of hours of entertainment, seems hard to go wrong here. if you hit it at the appropriate time you can even get it for practically a steal; and i'm assuming more sales will be on in the future. generally this seems like a good one to go for if you are just looking for the pinball feel, and think you would enjoy the themes for which you can get tables...if you are an oldskool pinball enthusiast, however, i would recommend checking out "Pinball Arcade" before FX2: it has emulations of many *real* tables, and can be a relatively fair price if you buy the Season packs rather than individual tables. i certainly can't afford it, but if thats the kind of experience you're looking for you're not likely to find a better deal. (or any other deal at all that i'm aware of!)

												This game reminds me of my golden amiga days spending my youth playing "Pinball Dreams", "Pinball Illusions", "Slamtilt" and the like.The only thing not so good about this game is that there is no scrolling when played in horizontal screen orientation BUT you can switch it to a 90 degree rotated screen display so the whole table is displayed on your screen at once and now that's a very neat feature after all. Of course you have to rotate your display too to play it properly in this scenario for best gaming experience ... ;)What annoys me a little is that the position of the flipper table's LCDs can't be fixed to the full width bottom or top of the screen like in good old amiga pinball games. Having this feature built in it would make it to the best modern pinball game known to me today (still filing "Slamtilt" under modern I must assume at this point ... ;).I totally recommend this game to you.Go buy it now! Presumably when it's on discount !!!(At the moment I'm writing this review you will get one table for free what makes it a really good offer even more than it is normally. What more can a true pinball addict ask for?)

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Since the 90s, EPIC Pinball was the ultimate pinball video game choice. With the arrival of Pinball FX on XBOX 360 in 2007, it finally found its match, and 3 years later with Pinball FX 2, it got its successor, a new pinball king.Zen Studios brought into the virtual pinball world, something that we have not seen before. Stellar ideas, ingenious presentation and perfect gameplay. Each table is a masterpiece of its own. So much to do on each of them and so much going on. Enriched with beautiful musical scores, great sound effects and animated 3D characters jumping around the tables.If you take a few minutes away from the action, and hold the camera button while moving the mouse around, you can look at all the details and love that was put in every square inch of every table and also of the surronding area where the tables are standing. I love and play every single table that was made, except 1, Extreme, which is not present in Steam version anyway.With so many tables present, with new ones coming all the time, you really cannot get bored, because when you make the whole circle through all the tables, the inital ones will feel so new and fresh again, you are ready for another tour, and another,.....Whatever the system, you're playing on, Zen Studios' pinball game is deffinitely the one you should not stay without.EDIT: 2 years laterNew tables keep on coming. Plenty of new ones for Marvel and Star Wars fans, but, which I appreciate most, several new original tables, conceived and designed entirely from scratch by Zen Studios. As much as I love the license based ones (Can't wait to get my hands on Aliens vs Predator tables. Hopefully I'll be able to get them during Summer Sale 2017), I am most excited by completely original tables. Understandably there are more of the linensed ones, but for the same reason, each new original feels that more special. If you look back we got scenarios like, fending off alien invasion, Don Quixote-like knight adventure to save a damzel, Indiana Jones-like quest for prescious artifacts, sneaking into wizards lair, mission to Mars, Roman conquests, exploration of the great ocean abyss,... And more recently we received a wild west cowboy adventure and got to play an actual football (soccer) match on a pinball table (Unfortunatelly, licenses for the European football teams have expired and are no longer available. But, the fictious Zen Football Team should be back as soon as possible, so you will still have the chance to buy it.).With the most recent Star Wars, Aliens and Marvel releases, hopefully a new original should be right around the corner.All I can do is recommend this game even more. I've been playing Zen Studios' pinball's, for around 8 years I guess, across 4 systems and I keep wanting more, and more is what I deffinitely get.If you like virtual pinballs you cannot miss out with this one. You have a chance to have a short demo of each and every table in the game, before deciding to pay for it, so no excuse not to give it at least a try.

Immediately went back and bought 20+ new tables (during Holiday sale), some tables for as low as $1, and packs of 4 for $3.49, incredible value.  Value aside, the game play, physics, visual stimulation are unbelievably outstanding.  I mean, it's so real, plays so much like real pinball, the physics are perfect.  Gameplay and physics aside, the best part about this, is it got my gf and family into it, whereas they would never be into Call of Duty or like Skyrim, they all absoltutely love pinball, everyone loves pinball.  So in that sense, it's a great family game and brings ppl together, it's competitive in a fun way in that you can always get a better score, and it's fun challenging friends and family.  Absolute must buy if you even remotely like pinball.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												WARNING: You may experience input lag!  You can fix it, but you have to do so manually.  See: http://steamcommunity.com/app/226980/discussions/0/666827315349070543/It's alright.  If you like pinball, maybe check it out.Menu's are acceptable.  The pinball mechanics work and that's about all I'm asking for here.  It's acceptable and if you like pinball you'll probably be ok with this game.I have not seen an already established table appear on this program yet, which has left me disappointed.  On the plus side, as this is a virtual program, the tables I've played on have mostly done things I've either never seen before or are not exactly feasible on a real life table, so that's a huge plus.However, quantifying if this game is good/bad is difficult as that mostly depends on the tables.  There are both bad and good tables and, from what I've played so far (5 or 6 tables) the name brand ones (star wars and marvel ones) are not nearly as good as the weird original ones (Tesla is pretty cool).  If I recall you can demo the program/tables, so there's that.Right now there are about 30ish tables available, so there's a lot of variety.  On the few I've played so far there hasn't been a lot of skilled play so much as flipper mashing, but that's also true for a lot of boards (I've only played one or two that were actually quite fantastic in real life).Anyway, if you like pinball to an unhealthy degree this might be worth checking out, although there are also pinball emulators out there that have real tables on them, so you might consider that as well.  As a buy?  Not terrible, I guess, but I would investigate the dlc (tables) further before you make a purchase of one.  I was pretty disappointed with the Marvel ones.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												TL;DC: Honestly I'm surprised how much fun this game is. WIth the varity of tables, amazing physics & graphics, and endless replay value, this is one of my top games.My previous experience with this game is a LOT of hours on Xbox, but I just got this on steam so that I could play on my monitor that tilts sideways for a better pinball experience. The key for me to getting a lot of enjoyment from each a table is to learn the rules, tricks and storyline (but don't try to do it all at once) - over time you'll learn to progress the table's story and / or help rack up your points. Eventually you'll master a table and by that point you'll already be addicted. A single 3-ball game can last quite a while once you've mastered a table. If you just aren't into a particular table, move to another. The table demos do a poor job of giving you a feel for how a game will play out over time, but at least you get an idea of the design. I purchased most of my tables based on reviews. A great first board is Epic Quest. A lot of players also love Fear Itself as a good starter table. By starter I don't mean they are "easy", it's just these boards are loved by a lot of players. Picking a dud as your first table could ruin your experience.The table designs are mesmerizing. The game play is much deeper than you might imagine. Every time I load up a new board, it feels intimidating, but I try to just focus on passages and taking it step-by-step. I never just read through the entire table guide. I'll learn part of it, master it, and then move on to learn something new. Unlocking a table's secrets on your own is half the fun, and every single table is differnt.I'm truely amazed at the creativity behind each table layout. Some are hareder than others, some more rewarding, some more about story, some about scores, and in the end, everything comes down to just how you play a particular table.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												one of the best pinball games i ever met (beside Pinball Dreams @early DOS times and Sierras 3D-Ultra Pinball later on). SO since those 2 games  are classic/old games this one took their place as my favorite pinball game on todays graphics and animations. Tables are made in nice interactive 3D graphics;  sound, physics and switching table-zones or with some extra taks makes each table unique.  My review is: NICE Work! They worked great on the tables - some are better some are less good. Tables are not that cheap, but in Bundles or on sale, prices are fair. And to mention this:  you can test the game! 1 table is completely free and all others can be tested least 1 ball / a specific and small ammount of gamepoints. So you won't waste your money like so many other games when you are not able to test a game before you buy.Update: since today new tables are integrated. StarWars and Portal Tables are really cool

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												This is most probably the best Pinball game out there. Yes these tables are not physically realstic in real-world , but they are still so much fun to play and watch, and most importantly the ball physics itself is excellent.You will sure find a table or two that appeals to you, and could spend the whole time playing them and not asking for more. They keep adding more tables and the collection is getting bigger and better. I like that they let you play each table for couple of minutes to get the feel of it before you buy.Only one thing I really don't like: You can't transfer tables from/to other platforms. I don't see why Zen Studios can't implement a unified system for all platforms. This is probably not a big issue, as I found myself enjoying the game on Xbox and the big TV instead of steam, so that's where I am going to invest in. I just thougt I would give this game a positive review for what it's in general, regardless of which platform you will enjoy playing on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Edit - The below review was meant to be a review of the Super Football League (Zen Team) table.This was a table I spotted released a while back, and I was excited about it.  Sports is a common theme for actual pinball, and it is nice to Zen take a dip into that genre.  I jumped on the -50% price during the summer sale, and I am not disappointed.  For what is the price of 3 plays (at 0.50 ea),  You get a very original table that really puts you into the illusion that you are playing a game of football (soccer).  I like the fact that the table hinges on hitting mostly ramp shots instead of a lot of gimmicks, but it does a nice job of building up the pressure on you to score when the time is right.  You almost forget you are playing pinball but not in a bad way.  This is a great table, and it doesn't seem to matter which team you choose as they seem to be the same except for the colors and individual players named through the course of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I have far too often been disappointed with following comments I read ahead and follow. Same with my own prejudices which must fall to the wayside in the decision for or against. I have personal preferences in favor of Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Steven Seagal; the directorial work of Robert Rodriguez and Tsui Hark; but I find that following my own preconceived notions do not work when deciding on something new.However, my friend recommended Pinball FX2, and I do like pinball games as a rule. I went ahead and took the free download and I must say the *free* Sorcerer's Lair table is pretty good; and being free, well ... if I was to be disappointed, I can't ask for much of a return. On this score I tried Pinball Arcade, and that one did indeed serve me great disappointment, even though it was free.My interest in this version has grown and this morning I looked for and found the Fantastic Four table at a price I thought to be a bargain; and well, here is my review. I caution any gamer, movie-goer, book reader or - well - consumer - to make up their own mind, this is my own opinion - It's a great game!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Simply put, one of the most immediately addicting games I have ever played; gorgeous and cleverly designed tables galore.If you don't like pinball, you probably won't enjoy this title. It does innovate, but it doesn't change what it is at it's core. +Endless replayable hi-score fun. +Original tables from the dev's with rich themes and additions that wouldn't be possible on a real table. +Graphics and sounds are what you would expect.+Leaderboards and stats galore. -From what I can tell, no real life tables. Those seem to be the focus of the other pinball game on steam, Pinball Arcade. Unfortunately, that game charges an insanely high amount for their table recreations - but that's exactly what they are, recreations of real tables, which is what Pinball FX2 lacks. My main gripe is that some tables made by Zen for Pinball FX are a little broken, whereas the tables in Pinball Arcade are based on real life tables which seem to be balanced better overall. The tables in Pinball FX2 are sold at a very fair price.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Played for only 2 hours So I decided to give this game a review. Here are the Pros n Cons of this game****Pros****1) Graphics are really nice, it can run on high quality graphics on a low computer2) Controls are easy, and even better if you have an Xbox 360 controller3) The download is quick, maybe 30 min to an hour.4) Tables are cheap and quick to get, there are collections you can unlock for dirt cheap prices. ****Cons****1) You get ONE free table, kinda sucks In my opinion, but they're cheap as i mentioned above.2) This is basically the same exact game as the Xbox has, just not with all the unlocked tables, if you want to spend $20 on a 360 game go ahead, otherwise get this game and buy only tables you want, for much cheaper prices.that's what I got so far. I rate it 9/10. Because of how fun it is.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Edit - The below review was meant to be a review of the Super Football League (Zen Team) table.This was a table I spotted released a while back, and I was excited about it.  Sports is a common theme for actual pinball, and it is nice to Zen take a dip into that genre.  I jumped on the -50% price during the summer sale, and I am not disappointed.  For what is the price of 3 plays (at 0.50 ea),  You get a very original table that really puts you into the illusion that you are playing a game of football (soccer).  I like the fact that the table hinges on hitting mostly ramp shots instead of a lot of gimmicks, but it does a nice job of building up the pressure on you to score when the time is right.  You almost forget you are playing pinball but not in a bad way.  This is a great table, and it doesn't seem to matter which team you choose as they seem to be the same except for the colors and individual players named through the course of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Simply put, one of the most immediately addicting games I have ever played; gorgeous and cleverly designed tables galore.If you don't like pinball, you probably won't enjoy this title. It does innovate, but it doesn't change what it is at it's core. +Endless replayable hi-score fun. +Original tables from the dev's with rich themes and additions that wouldn't be possible on a real table. +Graphics and sounds are what you would expect.+Leaderboards and stats galore. -From what I can tell, no real life tables. Those seem to be the focus of the other pinball game on steam, Pinball Arcade. Unfortunately, that game charges an insanely high amount for their table recreations - but that's exactly what they are, recreations of real tables, which is what Pinball FX2 lacks. My main gripe is that some tables made by Zen for Pinball FX are a little broken, whereas the tables in Pinball Arcade are based on real life tables which seem to be balanced better overall. The tables in Pinball FX2 are sold at a very fair price.

content:

												Good game not all tables are great but most are very good. The avenger pack with fear and avengers is a little on the annoying side because of all the ramps you need to hit to get anything going and the more then not balls drains down the middle and sides a lot more then should be. Mars is a great table along with the star wars tables and epic quest is a  nice easy table that flow nicely. Blade is another good one for just having a good ball flow. The hulk table drives me nuts because of all the repeated talking he does, you will find out  its repeated every 2 minutes. Ugh. The hulk table is nice and I did enjoy it minus the voice talking. Earth Defense is a nice table with plenty of space and lots of action and no cheap ball drops. For pinball fans this is a no brainer pick some up and enjoy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												In the past i grew up with a limited set of games on the computers. One of them was a little pinball game called "balls of steel" which had me playing for hours. Ever since i rarely saw any pinball games except for a few tiny titles every so often, none matching the quality and fun of a good pinball game. Then Pinball FX 2 appeared on steam and it was like i got a toy i always wanted as a kid, but never got.Pinball Fx2 is a perfect pinball game that makes use of current tech (Yet not too much) to make for a fun game that can run on a wide scale of systems. Sure it aint perfect as on rare occassion a physics glitch occurs, but it comes far closer to perfect then any other title i know of.Only real downside is the hefty price-tag if you are planning to get all Tables.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Pinball FX2 and Zen Pinball 2 are one in the same, produced by Zen Studios.  For the sake of this review I will refer to FX2 for the entire franchise.  I purchased, and repurchased it for PS3, Wii U, Xbox 360, and finally Steam, each platform being better than the last.  The pinball physics, variety and challenges are endless, with each table being better than the last.  The old tables have not aged well, but there is a lot of fun to be had here.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Pinball FX2 goes beyond what real world pinball tables could do, making extraordinarily deep and varied experiences. Tables vary a bit in quality, from very good to wonderful, and I've yet to find a table I didn't enjoy at least a little bit.  But be warned, tables do have to bought separately (or in some small bundles), so the upfront cost is not the final cost.  But as long as you're aware of that, this is the best computer pinball there is (Pinball Arcade is a close second, with its focus on real world table recreations, so if that's what you're looking for, go there instead).

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Pinball FX2 is a very polished product. The tables are diverse and well thought out, and common shots and ramps rarely drain directly unless you've put some weird spin on the ball.In terms of bugs, the game is solid, but for me required a couple of system tweaks to make it playable due to what was otherwise pronounced input lag (disable v-sync and drop the "maximum pre-rendered frames" setting to 1 in your video drivers). Check out the pinned thread in the Steam forums for more details. Additionally, for me, the Spiderman table is completely unplayable as a ball goes missing half way through a game and never reappears.Neither of the above problems was resolved when I recently refreshed my system with a new install of Windows 8 64, upgraded from Windows 7 64.A huge amount of work has gone into table designs, every table puts its own unique spin on things and all are originals. This means that they are also a little more forgiving than many real world tables as they don't have to factor in eating your money.All tables reward skill, and generally offer a good variety of modes, multiballs and combos to keep things interesting.The ball physics are excellent, although ball speeds are perhaps a little bit faster than real world tables (noticeably faster on some tables, less so on others). Regardless, if you are already a fan of real-world pinball you won't have any trouble picking things up where you left off.Even though I've been a die-hard pinball fan for many years, I've tended to shy away from electronic versions as they've not given me the same satisfying real world sense of interactivity, from the slap of the flipper buttons to nudging the table.Pinball FX2 doesn't solve this lack of physical interactivity, in that controls are simply left and right space bars for the flippers and the control keys and space bar to nudge the table.In my case, however, I've recently acquired a new mechanical keyboard, and if you're like me and need a bit more physical feedback to recreate the experience you're used to I can highly recommend the investment. My mechanical keys now provide exactly the right tactile slap from hitting the flippers.I also find that, as I'm a decent player, most tables are generous in awarding kickbacks, and therefore my main reason for nudging is rarely necessary (and if you're not a decent player, why would you even try?).The sound is quite effective at ball-clack noises, bumpers and the like.My biggest gripe with the game is that some tables get carried away with the video-game potential through such things as glowing balls, sped-up balls in certain game modes, and full video-game style mini games. If you are someone, like me, who prefers a more 'pure' pinball experience, you will find that these tables can get irritating very quickly. Thankfully, there is enough variety (if you can afford it) to largely stay away from the more painful examples. I've also turned off ball glow trails in options as I was finding the ball glow was sometimes interfering with my ability to read the ball.As you will observe with a quick overview of the available DLC, Zen Studios have taken full advantage of its Star Wars and Marvel licenses. In my view this is a shame as the non-licensed tables feel far more creative, original and varied than those heavily reliant on movie imagery and sound-bites.Overall, however, I've had a lot of fun with Pinball FX2 and can enthusiastically recommend it.

number of helpful: 12 of 26 people (46%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												You have to ask yourself one question.  How long can you keep Isaac Newton from laughing about your balls?This.  This is my favorite game on Steam.  Pinball Arcade is just as good, but the currently impossible-to-manufacture tables that aren't trying to chew your quarters really lets your mind go to a zen state, and then a Logitech F310 or controller of choice becomes an extension of your consciousness.  Don't play for a high score, or for extra balls, the only one that matters is the last one on the table.  It's difficult to tell people what drives a person to play this game, but it's easy to recommend to everyone, if you are in the right mood to battle physics.9,5/10 equal to Pinball Arcade.  Play for fun, and keep this bit of trivia in mind: it costs $2 to play one game of pinball in real life.  Play a table in this game 100 times over the course of a year or more?  The value doesn't even make sense unless you remember being in an arcade with these competing with Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter.  Here, you don't have anyone judging your technique, there's a guide for every table a Start button or Esc key away explaining every detail you could ask about how to destroy a table.  Video guides if you have a friend you really want to beat, but your opponent is really yourself - Guardians of the Galaxy is a really energetic, fun table, and so is the South Park pack if you like the show.  The Walking Dead table is amazing if you've played the Telltale RPG series.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Edit: According to some other reviews on here, there is a new Terms of Service with some questionable new policies. My review is of the game itself and I have not played in several weeks so I was unaware of it. Check out some of the other reviews here or research a bit before downloading. I apologize for the outdated review. I'm 23. Though nowhere near old enough to have memories of arcade pinball machines, I am old enough to have nostalgia over virtual pinball games! Simple games are often the best in my opinion, and everyone knows how to play pinball. It is quite literally two buttons. Pinball is a concept any kid can understand. My free time after school often consisted of running home to play, of all things, Microsoft Windows Pinball. Looking back, it's amazing to me - a game that came free with our operating system had captured my attention for hours. On the go, I had 1999's Pokemon Pinball on my GameBoy Color. Now this one was more advanced - it had the Red table, and the Blue table (named after the Pokemon Red and Blue games), and they were different. I was amazed. I was addicted. I mentioned I like simplicity. To me, there is something to the objective of getting a high score. Challenging yourself, topping a friend's score, the way your heart starts beating fast as you realize you're edging in on a top score - these are some of the best feelings in gaming.Pinball FX2 gets that. It understands the simplicity of the fun that comes from hitting a little silver ball around a table, trying to top that last score. It eggs you on. It notifies you when you're about to beat that score, or a friend's score. It also understands my childish excitement when I saw Pokemon Pinball had two options for tables. It has dozens of tables, and I have yet to play one I didn't greatly enjoy. Zen has many original tables within the game, and there are some great licensed tables as well. You can find tables from the Marvel and Star Wars Universe. Some more series you will recognize are The Walking Dead, South Park, and Plants vs. Zombies. I will say Pinball FX2 is a bit heavy on the Marvel and Star Wars (so if you're not into those, there are a reduced number of tables you'll be interested in), but since you buy tables separately, you can just choose not to buy them. The quality and originality of every table has impressed me every time I try a new one, so even if you're not into the "lore" (as I'm not crazy on the Marvel universe), you may find the tables still well worth playing.Here is also a bit about the "pay structure" - the game is "free to play" technically. Everyone who downloads Pinball FX2 gets the Sorcerer's Lair table, which to be honest is a fantastic table you could entertain yourself on for hours. One of my favorites for sure. Anything else is sold separately, in "packs" (ie. the Star Wars and Marvel packs) or as individual tables. They are ALWAYS on sale during Steam sales so if you are eyeing a table but don't want to pay full price, I recommend just adding it to your wishlist and waiting!If you love pinball games, give it a go. Try the free table, see what you think. There is something to kicking that little (virtual) ball around the table, which must be why I'm 23 and still playing the same game I was when I was 8.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
So tell me of this mysterious gameAhhh, Pinball, a superficially simple but subtly complex game.A game where heroes are forged in the fires of force and geometry, a game where dreams are shattered by that evil temptress called gravity.A game that separates the men from the boys, the women from the girls and the Wizards from them all!Welcome to the intense, extreme and often emotional sport of Pinball!I wish to be a wizard separated from boys and girls! This isn’t a journey to be undertaken lightly my friend, but if you are sure, I will teach you!Come with me as we traverse the pleasures and pitfalls of this wild and exhilarating sport.Throughout the course of this review we’ll journey through the basics, the concepts, the joys and the jargon.I’m going to give you all the information you’ll need to be a pro, as for becoming a wizard?Well that’ll take hard work and dedication, but I have faith in you my prodigy.Field of Dreams As a potential paragon of pinball, you will first need to be aware of the forum of the faithful that is the arena for this glorious sport.This arena or playing field takes the form of a table, but not just any table, this is a table with a slant, rising upward before you like the altar of aspiration it truly is.As an aspiring Baron of the Balls, you will take your place at the base of this tilted table of temptation. You should strive to feel comfortable here; this is where dreams are made.Balls of SteelOn to this table you can launch a steel ball, your avatar on this plateau of promise.The tormenting tilt of the table will then conspire with gravity to defeat you as your ball succumbs to their merciless grip and begins to roll downwards towards impending doom.Impending Doom?That’s right. At the base of this alluring alter of ambition lies the abhorrent abyss of agony, the pit, the void, the gaping mouth where all balls are inevitably sucked.Despite your skill level, this will eventually happen to you. It is the destiny of every ball to be sucked into the mouth eventually.But fear not friend, you are not defenceless, you can fight back.They Call Him FlipperOn this tilted board of dreams you also have some interactive devices the pros like to call “flippers”At the press of a button you can utilise these “flippers” in an attempt to intercept the rolling steel ball and change its path, hopefully away from the previously mentioned hole which is waiting to consume your ball.Nice PinsIf that isn’t enough excitement for you, the table also has strategically placed targets which we’ll call pins.Although your primary objective should always be to avoid the devouring pit of doom at the base of the table, you also have the secondary goal of trying to hit the various pins with your mighty ball of steel.So it’s a game of pins, balls and tables.If you want to sound like a “real pro” you should refer to this pinned platform of perils as a “Pinball Table”Pinball WizardBut wait, there’s even more. The order in which you strike these “pins” can also be important.If you strike the correct targets consecutively you may be awarded with additional points to help boost your score.That’s right; the pinball table isn’t only there to confound you with its attempts to swallow your balls.You can also quantify your prowess through the facility of a score.This is where the true pinball wizards achieve their bragging rights.If only there was some sort of training simulatorSo, now you’re ready to master the mechanics of the fickle mistress that is pinball, but which game should you choose to hone your developing pinball powers?Surprisingly, when looking for the simulated experience of this seductive sport, you’ll find that the market isn’t exactly flooded with titles.Sure, there are a few options out there, but if you’re serious about your pinball wizardry then the “go to” game at the time of writing is Pinball FX2 and best of all the price of admission is free.Free is GoodMost of us can afford “Free”, in fact it’s my favourite price point for a game.So what do you get for an investment of zero? A pretty well designed pinball table with all the bells and whistles you’d expect from a digital version of the game, that’s what.As well as the free table to cut your teeth on (which will likely give you many hours of game time on its own before you get bored), you also get the chance to enjoy a few minutes play time on many of the additional tables available to purchase in the game.More PleaseWhen you do decide to move on from the starting table, the choice is vast, from the generically themed tables of Rome and Tesla through to Star Wars and The Walking Dead, you’re sure to find a table to suit your mood.The additional tables are reasonably priced, and although you’ll undoubtedly have your own favourites, they are all of a high standard, expertly designed and fun to play (and yes, I’ve played through most of them)Let’s Get PhysicalThe physics in Pinball FX2  is spot on. The ball bounces around exactly as you’d expect it too, the motion is fluid, the flippers respond smoothly and no matter how frantic the action gets, everything rolls along nicely.Master your BallsPinball FX2 is an outstanding title in the genre; it sounds good, it looks amazing and it plays better than the real thing.There’s a score table out there waiting to put your name up in lights. It is time for the student to become the master.Go now, Show the world what you can do with your balls!( To view the full review (and others) please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/ )

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Pinball FX2 (known on some platfroms as Zen Pinball 2) a solid pinball game with tight controls and good physics. What helps to set this apart from other pinball simulators is that the game is not limited to things that are possible on real tables, such as character interaction or varying minigames, also the wide array of licensed tables (mostly from Mavel and Star Wars) might be a draw.The biggest downside i've seen of this game so far is that the game is sold in pieces, which may or may not be a good thing depending on your tastes. There are various packs, single table purchases, and bundles to choose choose from that it might be overwhelming, but the game does allow for you to demo every table for a few moments. Also because this is how the game is set it, its constantly reminding you of the content you do not own.There is also a ton of customization options from graphical settings to viewing angles that you can find the layout that works best for you. Sadly, this version of the game is missing its online multiplayer component, leaving the only form of competition you can have up to various leaderboards that can be in general or between your Steam friends.Ultimately if you need one Pinball game, this one can do the job nicely between its feel and wide table variety, just dont be weary of the game being sold in pieces.DISCLAIMER: There is apparently some nasty documentation with the wording in the End User License Agreement that could allow the game to be updated to serve as spyware on your PC. I have done some research before I ever downloaded the game and discovered the game itself (as of this review) does not do this at all. Zen Studio's also recieved a big enough backlash that they said they'd ammend the EULA some time ago but have yet to for reasons unknown. I am personally confident both developer Zen Studio's and publisher Microsoft Studio's would not be so foolish at this point in time to gather untold information outside of the game itself at this point. If the presense of this info on the EULA still is making you uneasy or you do not wish to keep tabs on this situation, i'd remomend just waiting until the EULA is altered to either remove that portion entierly or to adjust it to clearly state they are only gathering background information in-game on your   usage and purchase habits(in the context of providing a better service or selection to its users).

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												"Reminds me how bad I am at pinball." 8/10These days pinball machines are nowhere near as popular as they once were, and even for a kid like me who grew up in the 90's before the whole "internet" thing really took over; pinball still wasn't very popular back then either. But it's been around for as long as most people can remember, and as far as I can tell, it's not going anywhere anytime soon. And I'm totally okay with that, because it's usually the simplest games that are the most fun to play, and are typically the hardest to master. At least, I think people can master pinball.If you've ever played pinball and enjoyed it, then I'm sure there was something about the machine that drew you to it in particular; maybe it was 'Star Wars' themed, or maybe it was modeled after ‘NASCAR’, or perhaps you liked the one based on 'The Sopranos'; regardless of your taste, the beauty of 'Pinball FX 2' is how many choices you get in tables. It's got everything you could ask for in terms of themes, and each table offers it's own unique story and intricacies, making them all feel different and original. And new ones are still being released too, so there’s always something to look forward to up on the horizon.Despite the significant drop in popularity, pinball machines are still being produced today, and typically appear in bars for drunks to enjoy. But if there aren’t any in sight, and you still feel the need to get your pinball on, this is a great replacement to sit back with a sixer, and try and run up some high scores. And the best part about each table is that you get to test it out for a few minutes before deciding whether or not you want to purchase it. There are a few pinball games on Steam, but I have to assume this is the best one out there. Download it today and give it a try, you've got nothing to lose; not even a quarter!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												One of the most popular pinball games. Follow your senses and let the days of the Star Wars series pinball machines get your light saber fingers moving. Or kick off a soccer game with your friends and then go play with South Park tables. No, then sit back and try your hand at the many other tables found in this collection of fun tables. Challenge your frineds to beat you or play with them in multiplayer mode for instant action. The more friends you have that play this game the higher your score will be in the end with shared point accumulator. This is not a slow paced game, eye and hand coordination is key. Being drunk, high or under the influence will not help your game. Distractions like children and pets can bring your game down so try to give them something else to do while you play. Enjoy your game and don't forget about the real world. Stop, go outside, stretch and visit the bathroom before returning to the game. Please pause the game if your child needs you and remember this is only a game.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												I have only played this for a little while.When I was little and Windows XP came with Pinball, it was one of the only games I played. I loved it because it was something to do...Now here we are a decade later and I find this game. While it is annoying you don't have more than one table free, it is pretty realistic. The UI is slick, the themes are pretty accurate, and there's something about it that gives you nostalgia. Now, I'm not old enough to remember Arcade Pinballs but I have played a real game before. This is pretty accurate to the formula. If it were any more realistic it'd be scary.Oh and a plus you can get the Portal table half off if you own the games.
