content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												One of the best pinball games out there.Pros:* Screen orientation/ rotation option available (can turn your widescreen monitor longways to play like a real table)* Highy detailed tables and visuals with fantastic animations and side theatre* Plenty of viewing angle options* Tournaments* Plenty of extra tables to purchase (at reasonable prices) with new ones being released from time to time* Great sound effects* Fun to play tables.Cons:* None really.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Pinball FX2 is frankly the best pinball game you will find on Steam. I'll keep this review short since it's just pinball and quite frankly there's little to say, but anyone interested in having a solid arcade feeling pinball experience should get this game.PROSFunGood Selection of tables Solid Feeling Controls, everything feels responsive and you never feel like you missed a ball thanks to a delayed flipper or anything else. Multiple table aesthetics to suit anyone's taste. Want an underwater themed table? It's there. Want a wild west themed table? It's there. Want a space themed table? It's there.Multiple camera angles to play around with so anyone can adjust the camera to their playstyle if they want a larger view of the table or just want to follow the ball. Plus they look cool and can be used to switch things up if it gets boring.The music and sounds for each table are niceIt looks pretty  CONS The game gives you one free table but you'll quickly get bored of that and want to buy some other tables which frankly feel like a rip. Most tables are three dollars which isn't that bad for the amount of quality you get with these tables, but still feels a little bit too expensive. I would just drop 10$ on the core pack which gives you some of the best tables in the game and buy the others which seem of interest to you. While not a big flaw for a free game, it's something to consider.Many of the tables are promotional tables for Star Wars, Marvel, or Football(Soccer to us Americans). While no-one is forcing you to buy these tables, they take up the majority of Tables offered by the shop and seem to be a lesser quality than most other tables. This could just be my personal preference, but the Venom table is my least touched table out of all the tables I own. I hear the Football(Soccer) tables are weird also. Lack of Windowed mode. This is really a game that needs windowed mode, but lacks it----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you have any interest in Pinball or are a Pinball enthusiast pick this game up, you wont be disappointed.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Pinball taken to 11Theres really not alot to say about the game play of Pinball FX2.  Its pinball. but its one of the best virtual pinball games i've ever played.  It has a sleek presentation, and the game play and physics feel really good.  and since its not a reality the table aren't bound by physical limitations so you can have things like people flying around the table or explosions that add to the presntation and polish.  I also like how even with these larger than life elements it still feels like pinball. no stupid gimicks. just a ball and flippers.  Now i'm talking about the over all experince here.  Some tables in the game are better than others and that will vary depending on what kind of pinball elements you like and how appealing a particlar tables theme is to you.  but reguardless there are a large variety of table you can purcahse and each one is will have the same level of quality, polish and presentation. If you need your pinball fix this is a good option

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I've mostly played this game on PS3 where it's called Zen Pinball, but it's pretty much the same here, and I've played it a lot.  The tables are almost without exception of excellent design.  The physics are great, there's a lot of view modes, the high score tables are great, new tables come out regularly, graphics and sound is awesome. I just can't say enough positive things about this game.  I'd never really played pinball before playing this, apart from putting in som quarters for a short game in rl pinball machines when I was a kid.  I didn't expect to get this addicted to it or that it would be so much fun.  Even though you'll suck at first most likely, if you just try to improve your own score and understand the tables you'll improve a lot pretty fast and then addiction kicks in.  If you can compete with a friend or more it's even more fun. You may not expect it or know it yet, but chances are you'll love it!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												This is what Pinball is suposed to look like in a virtual enviroment!While other Pinball Games focus on bringing exsisting tables on your device. Pinball FX2 takes advantage of the virtual enviroment and provides very dynamic tables with mechanics that are impossible in the real world. Latest example the Portal Table, that brings the famous Portal gameplay to Pinball.2.99€ per Table is a reasonable prize for the Tables, since you can play as long as you want and the effort of making those very dynamic tables is quite high. So 2.99€ is a very fair prize. Also, some Tables and Packages go on Sale from time to time, so you can save a buck or two if you're patient.All in all, Pinball FX2 is currently the most original Pinball Game out there, with unique tables that are not stuck in the past.

												It is Pinball taken to its next logical evolutionary step. I can not find enough words to heap on the praise this game and its many tables deserve and believe me, I tried hard. I have a Thesaurus open in front of me and it just isn't helping. The tables are bright, engaging and tremendously fun. The sound effects and themes chosen are fantastic and it combines all the amazing fun and real terror of real pinball. Losing your ball is as disappointing as it is in real life! Can't beat that! The Star Wars Tables are great, and the new Portal Pinball table looks well worth acquiring. If only they would do a Jurassic Park table, just like the Data East one from 1993. One can dream! Get your favorite tables, put your quarters away and play till real life gets in the way!

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
Pinball FX 2 is not a realistic pinball experience, but it's equally addictive and has a charm of its own.Pros:- The FREE table is fantastic and gives a great indication of what PinballFX has to offer.- The price of each table is very reasonable, especially when compared to other pinball games.- Really great mixture of original and acquired IP tables.- Great visuals, nice graphic styling. - Deeply designed tables, even more so than many real tables. - Cabinet support (if you're fancy enough!)- Table guides that actually take you around the table, allowing you to form a stratergy. - Leaderboards. - Very stable build. Cons- Ball feels a bit light/weightless, not like real tables.-  The UI is a bit of an eyesore.- The audio is a bit too 'clean' for a pinball table, bit of a strange gripe but hey. - Some audio can be repetitive and annoying sometimes (South Park is one of the worst for this)***NOTICE TO ZEN***Although tables based on existing intellectual properties are great, you should not neglect to continue to create originals! Some of the most enjoyable tables are your own (Paranormal, Sorcerer's Lair, Epic Quest). Tables with IP's sell much better I'm sure, but It would be awesome if we got another original once in a while!Thanks for making a great game!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
REGARDING THE EULA: I looked further into it. It's been changed again.The ZEN Services may include third party dynamic behavioral in-game advertising technology which enables tailored advertising to be temporarily uploaded into the ZEN Services on your device and replaced while you are online. For further information please read the Privacy Policy.Now you may be thinking that the game will be full of ads. Nope, that's not the case. I'd say it's rather limited, actually. It's mostly because of all the promotional pinball tables that you can buy (e.g. Star Wars tables, Marvel tables). No ads popping into your face. There's really nothing to worry about.Whether it is still collecting information like your location/IP addrees, hell if I know. Most of this only applies to you IF you open a ZEN account. Now I'm not sure whether the game automatically creates a ZEN account for you using your Steam account information, which it can access of course (like almost every game).Now about the game:I've been longing for a good Pinball game since Pinball Fantasy on the Amiga. This game is pretty much what I wanted. Even the ball physics work almost the same way as in Pinball Fantasy.There was 1 huge problem I had with this game, which was input lag. I found a fix for it on the community formus.As for the cameras, the 3rd and the last camera setting works for (since I'm used to Pinball Fantasy), the rest are indeed pretty bad though. Most of them are set pretty low which gives a very skewed view on the table.As for the tables themselves, looks like the original tables are the best although also a bit cheesy (but hey, if classic pinball tables are your thing, then you'll love them). The Star Wars tables and most of the promotional ones, although they look good, most of them are pretty boring. I absolutely recommend the Portal table though. It's on of the most creative tables out there.The pricing seems reasonable to me (I mean, they could've asked for like 30 dollars and include 4-5 tables as usual with pinball games). Most of them also come in packs, so you can save a bit + there's always steam sales.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Usually, if a game prominently features balls, my review is going to contain a lot of puerile humor.  I cannot promise you I will make it through this review without discussing smacking balls, handling balls, cradling balls, being swarmed by balls, having your balls sucked down the hole....  You get the idea.  I am apparently still ten years old and there's just no helping that sort of thing when a game is fundamentally about how well it treats your balls.  I want to try and start this review on a sober note, though.  I am deadly serious about pinball.  I love pinball.  And, let's be honest, you do too or you wouldn't be reading a review about simulated pinball.  In the realm of games pinball is like a sharpened stick compared to the large hard-on colliders that are video games today.  But I still remember playing this one wicked old machine about a million years ago in my friend's aunt's basement.  We played that♥♥♥♥♥♥all night long, stomping the old high score into the dirt.  It was an old cowboy themed table, with no story or complex goals to achieve.  It was just a silver ball, a couple paddles, some targets, bumpers, and a ramp.  Your only goal was to keep the ball in the air, letting it cause as much chaos as possible while the score rolled up.  That ball was so ♥♥♥♥in' heroic.  And I don't mean like kids with cancer or a flower growing up through a crack in the sidewalk.  This was like the guy from "They Live!" on a completely hopeless mission that he's got to do anyway because he's a badass.That got rambly.  But you know what?  I don't care!  I measure every pinball experience I have against that cowboy table and the other pinball games I've played.  Come on, you do it too with your own tables.  Pinball's a nostalgia thing.  That's just how it is.  So to review Pinball FX2, I've got ask myself: how does this compare to the cowboy table?  How 'bout all the other real and simulated tables I've played?The answer, like the game's protagonist, is gray and all over the place.  What Pinball FX2 does well, it does really well.  What it does badly is just inexcusable.  (And I played most of the non-free tables outside of my Steam account so my play time is higher)What does it do well?  Well, there are visually interesting tables, with goals that pantomime simple stories and give you huge bonuses if you manage to meet certain conditions.  They're very much like the pinball machines I remember from arcades in the 90s.  I very much appreciate that the aesthetic of the boards is kept artificial and mechanical like a real table, but they aren't bound to that rule.  There are some imaginative, organic models and they use lighting and particle effects as you'd expect from a modern game.  It doesn't ruin the pinball experience, but justifies a pinball video game because you can do impossible things you could only dream of doing with your balls in real life!  And such variety!  Break out a new table, load your balls in the shaft, and enjoy shooting them all over such beloved characters as Spider-Man, Princess Leia, and King Arthur. The music is fairly engaging and, for the most part, the sound effects are satisfyingly weighty.  The game makes a good effort putting the camera how you want it with several different perspectives, from zoomed in on the ball, to hovering above the entire table.  It's not perfect, though, because it can't be.  Let's face it, boys, in real life when there are some perfectly formed spheres in front of you, all your focus is on them even though you're keeping the periphs on everything else that's going on.  But while it's all flattened out on your monitor that's just not possible.  Still, they did the best they could.  And, as playing pinball is like making love, they give you options to adjust the angle of the table and thus the speed of the ball.  Though, as in making love, doing so will disqualify you from the leaderboards.So what does it do so badly?  Well, a few things.  The physics feel a bit off.  Woah!  That is seriously bad!  That is the one thing you need to be correct for a pinball game.  Yeah, but they're not  too  off.  I'll freely admit it might even be my imagination, but I swear the ball doesn't always behave consistently when I trap and shoot it from the same part of the flipper.  The gravity feels about right, but once in awhile you'd definitely hear me screaming "BS!" at the screen.  Granted, I might do that with a real pinball machine and I might just suck from not having played enough pinball.  However, despite having controller support for nice modern pads like the 360 controller that has those nice analog shoulder buttons, you can only smack the paddle at full strength.  Now that might be great if you have children acting up, but pinball requires a gentler touch: floating your ball from one flipper to the other, releasing your balls as if gently kissed by an angel.  That's pinball, baby!  And while that might seem really petty to you guys, remember I'm putting Pinball FX2 against the cowboy machine and that is a serious failure.  At least other computer pinball I've played has been aware of placing different force upon the ball depending on what area of the paddle it's leaving, and Pinball FX2 doesn't roll that way.  When you hit your balls that hard all the time it just doesn't feel good, man. Alright, so that's bad.  Damning I would say.  But a couple of you might just shrug and say "what do you really expect from computer pinball?" or even, "You're only noticing those faults because Pinball FX2 is actually sort of close to real pinball unlike other computer games!"  Fair enough.  But let Pinball FX2, who is about to die, salute you, because I am about to signal the end of its days in this arena.  It succeeds somewhat by having a variety of tables, but that variety is superficial.  Every table is ultimately a 90s table with complicated goals, LED readouts, and animatronic trickery (animated trickery here).  Nowhere to be found is the simple cowboy table, where just keeping the ball in the air and maybe trying to get a whole group of targets down is all you need.  There's a purity in that experience, where a silver ball crashing around uncontrolled is still a win condition, from smashing the spinner out of the gate to careening off the last ill-fated bumper and down the drain.  Those tables aren't here, nor is anything in that minimal, old timey vain.  It's all the same glut of particles and complex models.  And remember, a Pinball game can only be about nostalgia, so leaving that out is real bad.I'm sure hard work goes into designing these tables, but I can't help but see them as just a reskin of the same free table.  I remember when I got "Take a Break! Pinball" on my Windows 3.0 computer.  It was awful, but for the couple of bucks I spent, I got half a dozen tables with distinct character.   When I was in middle school, I got a free pinball CD with three  tables from a cereal box that had good graphics for the age and played satifyingly if not like the real thing.  (It was probably not a cereal box.   It would be dumb to have a CD in a cereal box.)  Point is: the business model for this game is just deplorable.  They'd ultimately charge you one hundred sixty US dollars for pinball reskins.  That makes me mad.  Now, I know, you're saying "just buy the ones you really want and leave the rest, dingus!"  Yeah, well, sorry.  I get a lot of games on Steam and I occaisionally get full triple A releases courtesy of my buddy Abe Lincoln.  That's five smackeroos for everybody keeping score.  For something that's so niche, so living on nostalgia, even for a perfect version (which this isn't), that's not okay.  For $10 I expect a full release (zing) for that sort of thing, not three skins.  Bottom line: if you can overcome that sizable problem or just play the free table, then Pinball FX2 might be as close as it gets to real pinball.   Otherwise, can't recommend.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Pinball FX2 has some fun moments, but the developer is misguided and with the latest update, has shanked it's players and has really lost focus on the direction the game is going.Anyone who plays this game seriously has saved games, because you can't possibly finish a good run in one sitting, they go for 5+ hours and a lot longer in some cases. Zen decided to ninja an update that destroyed all saves across all tables and didn't warn the community ahead of time, even though it was known it would destroy saves. The condescending pop-up message confirms this. Top it off with the random crashes means you don't have a lot to look forward to other than frustration and wasting your time.The direction of all the new tables is this: Disney / Marvel. Zombies.    Don't expect much else. It's clear that the team has given up trying to be original, and like, say, Hollywood, just rehashes others' ideas, believing it will get a bigger response based on nostalgia and moronic fanboy response. Speaking of fanboys... The community has some good people but don't expect much give and take. Don't expect to be critical of anything without a bevy of uninvited losers with pacman avatars to go all fanboy attack on your comments / screenshots / whatever.This is ultimately the fallout of the fun in the game, in the long term. The people get annoying and if you don't tow the company's line, you will be bashed. Not by everyone, but you can't get away from the truly douchey people. Quality is hit or miss on the newer tables;  i.e. the Star Wars line are poorly exectued with a couple of exceptions and I expect this general trend to continue, as they seem to be going for style over substance.Do not buy. Pinball Arcade is a decent alternative for now.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												The four tables I purchased are derivative and have either an odd number of flippers, or asymmetric upper flippers, that are only useful for very specific and difficult shots (e.g. ball lock on Biolab). The tables also all suffer from strange bumps from the slingshots and sometimes the tip of the flippers that fire the ball right down the centre out-ramp (drain) before any reaction can be made; they try to address this problem with a ball save feature, but it happens too often and quickly becomes demoralizing. Also, the scoring feels "off" or disproportionate and takes forever to get a score above 10 million on any of the tables. The only success I've had is with the free table and I had to play for almost an hour to get 230 million and it became more of a chore than fun. Once I got that high score I "retired" the table and haven't played it since. The graphics are amazing, stunning even, but flashy graphics does not a good game make. I found Pinball Arcade to be have generally better physics and game-play. I won't be spending any more money on this game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												This is, hands down, the best pinball experience you can have without an actual pinball machine. The tables are fantastic with tons of scoring options and the challenges and missions are lots of fun. This game is great for casual fans looking for a quick pinball fix and hardcore fans trying to move their way up the leaderboard.I can see where die-hard pinball fanatics wouldn't be into pinball FX2. The game's biggest downfall IMO is the physics aren't actual, real life, perfectly emulated, like one would find on a real pinball table. They aren't perfect, but they are really really close and the best you can find on a digitized pinball platform.As fun as this game is, it becomes so much better when you have a friend who is competing with you taking away the high scores on a table challenging you to improve your game in order to take them back.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												The Pinball Arcade has real-world simulations of tables. This has the most realistic physics engine ever, with fancy tables as well. I don't have much to say about this table, but what I love about this game the most is the physics engine. It has the most realistic physics and sounds I've ever heard in a pinball game. The pricing is above reasonable, but it's also tables that don't exist in the real world, which is what I'm more interested in with a pinball game. That physics engine keeps me coming back though, and I know it's strange to have that as a selling point, so I'll say this instead: What if Zen Studios and Farsight Studios got together and combined FX2's physics engine with TPA's pinball simulations of all those classic Gottlieb, Bally, Williams and Stern tables?

content:
Posted: January 2
This is a very good for stress relief and has ignited my love of pinball. The free table, Sorcerer's Lair, is excellent and you could sink hours into that alone (which I did). I bought a bunch of tables during the Winter Sale and this has become my favorite piece of entertainment. I really like using the Steam controller and mapping the flippers to the big touch pads. It's much easier on my hands than the triggers and feels more natural.I have, so far...All of the Season 1 & 2 Marvel tablesPortalBalls of Glory (Family Guy, American Dad, Bob's Burgers, and Archer)South Park (Super-Sweet Pinball, Butters’ Very Own Pinball Game) All Original and Core pack tablesWith the sale, I ended up spending around $26 for 44 tables.I've focused mostly on the Marvel ones so far, and have experienced no technical issues with any of them. Some people had issues with the Spider-Man table getting the ball stuck and Deadpool crashing, but I have not experienced this (I've played the Spider-Man table quite a bit but Deadpool sparingly, so as always, YMMV).So far my favorites are:Moon Knight (good flow, great for combos… my total favorite so far)Spider-Man (I may be biased, I love Spider-Man)Infinity Gauntlet (this one is just madness)Butters’ Very Own Pinball Game (very charming) Captain America (well done theme, clear missions)The licensed tables are done very well with exception to the Marvel tables based on movies. The voice acting is horrendous and at times even distracting. I'm assuming there were legal complications with using the real actor’s voice clips, but I really think they could have done a better job. This isn't an indictment of the tables themselves, just the presentation. The others like South Park (and the rest of the cartoons) have clips from the show and are handled much better (even if they are overused a little, especially the South Park Super-Sweet Pinball).I'll start reviewing the packs individually but I wanted to give a little overview for anyone considering jumping on board. I'd recommend buying a few tables that you really want then waiting for a sale. If you get into it, you'll easily find them worth the cash, but I would never have bought as many tables as I did without the sale. I haven’t played anything pinball in years and I’m far, far, from a good player, but this is really an excellent way to wind down after a hard day and kick those stressful thoughts away.NOTE: Before posting I noticed the negative reviews due to the EULA. I’m going to look into this a bit and possibly even change my recommendation. But for now, I’m focusing on the fun stuff.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												PINBALL Hmmm....I started and have loved playing pinball since before arcades and video games existed. A quarter bought you 5 balls and 2 of them, bought you 3 games. Pool Halls are where you found a few machines to slap the ears and knee the coin box of your favorite machine. Yes I am that old. That being said...I have been extremely unimpressed with video recreations of pinball until now. Pinball FX2 hits the the target @ the bullseye. Zen has captured the heart of pinball in this version. The physics are spot on. The ball reacts to the flippers near perfectly. Trick shots, and saves can happen just like in real life. The ball can drain straight down the center or to the side just like the real thing. The tables....I own 12 tables as I wtite this review. I pick my tables based on playing the demo version that the game allows. I have played real life tables since the days they where more mechanical then electronic. I can tell enough, from the demo's all of the tables are heavly tested, not just for skill level but play style as well. I have found several tables that meet my taste. If you enjoy pinball you will find something in your flavor as well. PRO's:No quarters lost at the arcade.Physics are spot on. Ball behaves very much like real life pinball.Flippers are responsive, and won't wear out with time.Full controller support (Highly Recommend)Tables are exciting and themed. Tables are well tested for playability.Game is highly polished.Adjustable screen orientation. (portrait mode)Possible to demo tables before buying. CON's:No glass pops or free game pops.Some tables may be a little busy or flashy.No old school tables. with more targets, slots, pockets, or bumpers.Some of the camera follows can be abrubt and distracting. Demo's shorter then I want. (but aceptable)Some tables not available outside of packs.Start screen displays all availabe DLC.My only peeve, is the my last con. I don't want to be told my collection is incomplete, if I don't want that table. There should be a tab to display available content. I only want to see my own collection on the title screen. Ding 1 point for this infraction only.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I don't usually play pinball games. In fact the only ones I did play were 20 years ago on my Amiga (Pinball Fantasies, Pinball Dreams and Pinball Wizard). However, recently I bought a couple of Pinball FX2 tables in a humble bundle. I have played 5 tables so far. Here are my impressions. The good is:- It's free! You can try one table and then decide if you want more.- There are a lot of different tables available in wide range of styles.The bad is:- Paying for each table feels like a collectible game.- The difference between the tables is mostly cosmetic. This is probably an inherent problem of pinball itself.- The sound effects, especially the ones containing movie quotes and such, get old very quickly.- However, the most important problem for me is that FX2 does not feel like a real pinball table. The ball is seemingly weightless as it makes no sound when it touches a wall and it sometimes changes direction in an unrealistic way.- Also, there is a noticeable delay between pressing the button and the flippers moving, which is the worst problem a game like this can have. How can you mess up controls that basically consist of two button?All in all I would not recommend the game. Feel free to try it, but be critical and remember that the other tables are not that different from the free one.

												This is a game where you simulate a dinosaur playing a pinball game.  You can't actually see that you are a dinosaur, but when you hit the flipper, there is a half-second delay before the flipper flips, simulating the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel your behemoth carriage.  I've tried to find an option in the settings to play as a human, but no luck.  My graphics card (AMD Radeon) software ALSO doesn't seem to have the "play as human" option that the developers allege it does, so I guess I am stuck as a dinosaur.  Needless to say, I will never pay anything for any of these tables, because they are impossible to play.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Pinball FX2 pairs classic pinball gameplay with themes from Star Wars, Marvel and more.Each table can be played for a limited period of time, so you are forced to buy tables to enjoy the whole gameplay.The look of the tables is good. The different pinball tables have variations and many of them have some little animations and action scenes. Super hero characters like the Marvel tables look like their comic book counter parts. This can be good in some instances and bad in others. The voice acting is generally good.The keyboard controls work well. The pinball action is adaptable in case you do not like the default set up. If you are a fan of Pinball games and you have some spare time, you can give Pinball FX2 a chance, but without payment, there will not be fun for long.Sounds 7/10Graphics 7/10Gameplay 8/10Atmosphere 7/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												This is quite a nice pinball-style game with many different tables available for purchase either separately or as part of a pack (both ways as DLC which merely unlocks the table already present in your installation of the game.  Each time a table is added to Pinball FX2, the size of the downloaded content increases by the size of the added table. This is because all of the tables are fully present so you can test them with certain restrictions (like time penalties, bonus penalties, etc.))Many of the tables are "enhanced" with features and elements that would be impractical or impossible on a physical pinball table, making them seem like more an evolution of pinball into "Pinball with added CGI" than what you'd find in a pinball emulator, which attempts to recreate exactly the pinball experience of imaginary or real-life pinball machines.  Some are based upon established concepts, like comics, superheroes, Star Wars, TV series, or other video games. Others are original concepts.Fortunately, you can download this game and play either Sorcerer's Lair, one of the early Pinball FX2 tables, absolutely free and unlimited in its accessibility, or you can try the other games it offers for a limited time per session (although it's been long enough since I last played Pinball FX2 that restrictions for unlicensed content might have changed).All tables, from what I've noticed, allow you, as the owner of the table, to access options presumably available to owners of actual arcade pinball machines who want to tweak their tables to bring in the most tokens or attract the highest number of players, allowing you to test the table's lights, in sections and individually, adjust difficulty, listen to sounds, change the simulated angle of the table, the weight of the balls, number of plays per credit, score listings, set it for free play, and many, many other things, as well as view the number of games played, balls played, time per ball, number of times the different kickbacks on the table have been activated in play and while what ball or feature was active, how many credits inserted, extra balls awarded, and basically get a very detailed statistical report of what has occurred with the virtual pinball table in your imaginary arcade since it was installed or since the last time you reset the table's statistics.Adjusting the options to something other than default will often disqualify your scores for inclusion on the leaderboards or for reception of some/all achievements for as long as the relevant option(s) are set to non-default setting(s).The Pinball FX2 description says the included, unlocked Sorcerer's Lair table is without restrictions with "no timed free play session, no ads, no gimmicks."Playing solo as I do, I have often noticed the many multiplayer benefits Pinball FX2 offers (because playing solo means I either don't appear in the listings or I'm the only player in the listings). You can play against your real-life in-person friends on the same machine in hotseat mode (like a real table), your Steam friends, or, apparently, friends you know on social networking sites, trying to best their high scores, times, achievements, etc., or merely pit yourself against the rest of the worldwide community (if you have no gamer friends who play this game or own the same tables you enjoy).(end of review 1.0)NOTE:From what I'm reading in the other reviews about the newest End User License Agreement, Pinball FX2 desires to access your social profiles for access to your linked friends and associates and IP address and device specs and location and likes and anything else that can be used to target "tailored" ads at you for advertising while you're playing the (hopefully UNowned) tables. Because I wouldn't link this game to any social networking sites I access, I don't see this as much of a problem. However, I have not yet read this "new 05-2015 EULA" so I can't comment more regarding whether I object to this "snooping" more than in principle. Is principle alone enough to give up a game which provides quite a bit of fun? Maybe, if it's as intrusive as some reviewers are claiming it is. Maybe not. I'll have to read the new EULA before I decide whether to change my initial review.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game while promising a classic pinball experience has far to many bugs "either bugs or my computer has a seizure every time the game boots up". For one of the simplest examples the left shift smacker only works half of the time and when it does actually realise you pressed the button it is somehow lagged and will likely miss the ball. Other than that "now at this point I may be getting nitpicky but if you actually take the time to read this far hopefully you won't mind" there is enough going on at the board while playing at a time to warrent a seizure warning " think I may have actually saw one on a later thought". Seriously, to keep up with whats going on and get anything decent of a score you would have to have for a lack of better terms super human eyes. Other that that on my playthrough I realised that considering this I had no time to read the paragraphs of writing on the board I was just trying to make sure I kept up with the ball its all luck untill you've played your heart out enough countless hours to know how each event actually works. In short my many many attempts at Sorcerers Lair were as you can all now guess very frustrating having a left clicker that only works if pressed just right and lag time must be taken into consideration also trying to read what the board said was useless because by the time I've read one sentence Ive already lost the ball. And yes I know that you can take time to read over the board before shooting the ball for all those of you out there that will likely argue this for ages but lets be honest here, this is pinball, pinball. Are you really going to sitdown and spend the anywhere between 25 and 50 hours to get a grasp for one board and how it works. To summarize that idea it's not fun when you have to put more effort into your pinball knowledge than that of even the most extensive video game lore such as Skryim, nobody wants to spend the time it took them "or at least I normally dont" to learn the lore of a fallout game or elder scrolls raging at a pinball game. In the end though if you like challenging game and I mean like pull your hair out get up and scream at the computer for not seemingly loading the game fast enough for you to hit that perfect ball just right, this is your game, get it, play it, rage it, then become annoyed like I did and write a rant about it in you'r spare time.

												Great game, iffy port.  Picked this up when it was on sale as it was cheap, but found out after the fact that it's missing the touchscreen integration that the Windows Store version of the same app has.  This is the fourth or fifth time I've been bit by Xen Studios's inability to do things cross platform (or even same platform) well.  Doesn't work with touchscreens, won't work on my Surface Pro in any playable fashion, and I've already bought all of this content on both my PS3 and iPhone/iPad that won't transfer between.  If you haven't ever owned this game at all before, it's worth picking up.  If you already own it on another platform or own tables somewhere else, stay far away.  If you played the demo through Windows Store and liked it, buy through Windows Store, do NOT buy through Steam, they are NOT the same game.

												I love a good pinball game.Unfortunately this is nothing like a good pinball game.  There is one 'free' table which changes occasionally (every month or so) and there are 21 other tables to play which lock you out after 60 seconds or 500,000 points.  When the trial is over, you are prompted to buy the board or get kicked out.Micro transactions are the pits.The paddle controls are wooden and the responsiveness of the tables leaves a lot to be desired (Just don't tilt.)  Honestly, if you are looking for a quick game of pinball, then this 1.5GB monstrosity, which is marked as ‘free’, isn’t it.The only positive elements to mention are the single "free" board, which is not terrible.  Purchasing the 'add-on' boards would get expensive quickly.  This is too bad really because the trial boards look interesting but 60 seconds isn't enough time to even get a feel for them and is really just frustrating.I can't recommend this game, sorry.

number of helpful: 13 of 32 people (41%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Can't recommend this one unless you are desperate for more pinball (I was). It's not pinball for pinball fans, it's pinball for fans of other things who want a "themed pinball" experience that is forgiving, simplistic, outrageous/action packed, full of unrealistic special effects, and not comparable to real pinball in any way except in appearance and scoring. Inaccurate but predictable ball physics and poorly designed levels mean you can spend 30 minutes racking up a high score doing the exact same things over, and over, and over, and over, only to find out not only is it not a high score, but there are dozens of pinball losers out there that have played the table for LITERALLY DAYS, 24+ HOURS, to get a score so ridiculous you wonder what the point of the game might be? It isn't fun for very long, it's VERY repetitive (you get bored frequently long before you run out of balls), there's no real target to shoot for scorewise, and there are maybe 5 good tables out of the 40 or whatever that are available. Oh, and the tables: weird, weird stuff. More than half the tables are superhero themed, Marvel and such, I don't know for sure I'm a pinball fan not a comic book fan. Also a lot of Euro Football Club (FC) themed tables were just added recently. I don't know, I'm not a football fan, I'm a pinball fan. There's a Plants vs Zombies table, but I'm not a PvZ fan... I'm a pinball fan. Seeing a trend?UPDATE 10/9/2014: This week Pinball FX2 got a 3.2gb patch that added Stereo Sound. Yup, stereo sound for 3.2gb, with still no update for multi monitors, physics, pincab setups, or a huge list of other things the community has demanded for years. Deleted. For good this time.UPDATE 6/1/2015: HAHAHAHAHAH @ this new EULA. Signing away all your rights to privacy, agreeing to 3rd party targeted advertising, giving Zen unlimited freedom to do anything they want with every piece of information you supply to them while using this game or your pinball account, and even forcing you to agree to 3rd party advertising privacy policies JUST TO PLAY THE GAME? What could possibly go wrong! I haven't touched this title in ages but at least it still provides comedy from time to time. Good thing I like black humor, eh? :D

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												First of all, do not be fooled, this is NOT a free game and it sure is not cheap. It costs over $40 to buy complete, as it is offered one table at a time. The better tables cost as much as a complete 3-years old game on sale whereas the not so good tables are cheaper. And now for the bad news.Problem No.1: the perspective is all wrong and there is no way to fix it. The back half of the table (including the back flippers in most cases) are hidden from view. You hear sounds, you see some movement yet you have no idea what's going on. There are ways to give a forced 3D view to a simulated pinball table; unfortunately the developers missed the ball in all of them ;).Problem No.2: the physics are screwed up. A pinball game is by definition a game of split-second decisions and unpredictability (yet consistent) gravitomagnetic reactions. So, I cannot imagine how anyone can claim of having fun with a pinball game that is inconsistent in its physics.Problem No.3: the graphics are forcibly low and the resolution is not modifiable. A barely playable game that is not even a eye-candy? I am sorry but I cannot recommend this to anyone. Microsoft’s Space Cadet (not to mention Austin Powers Pinball) were far better pinball games. In all honesty, I have had more fun with pinball games on my smartphone. And I have a... Windows phone!

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												I play this game a hell of a lot, at least by my standards, and have some 150 hours+ played... so you'd think with me playing this game so frequently, i must like it a lot, right? WRONG!This game is pretty much gaming heroin, it's got me well and truly hooked, and that is the only reason i continue playing. And i mean the ONLY reason, because despite having all the DLC tables, i vehemently detest every second i'm playing this thing. This game subjects you to unbearable frustration unlike any other. For every go you enjoy because you do well, there are around 50 goes where it makes you look and feel like you've never started the game before, you do so badly. Yes there is skill involved, but also huge amounts of luck. The number of times a potential new best score is terminated because the ball gets shot straight into an out-lane or straight between the central flippers without you having the chance to do a single thing is ridiculous. In my 150+ hours i have NEVER, not once, had a go where at least one ball wasn't totally wasted.If you do something crazy, like... oh i dunno... actually not play this game for 1 day, then that is long enough to ensure you become so rusty you play like a total first-timer. Or if you do something truly masochistic, like play this game every day, it will still go in cycles so you once again go back to playing like a total first-timer. Except, of course, now you have your own personal high scores that show to you how well you should be at this game, as you struggle to barely reach 5% of that high score in your next 50+ attempts.This game is NOT fun, it is NOT enjoyable, but you WILL constantly play it because it hooks you almost immediately. The base game with first table is free and you can try all other available tables for a short time before buying them as DLC's. But spare yourself endless frustration and don't try it! I hate this game with a passion and wish i had never found it on here!And before people comment saying i only hate this game because i'm crap at it, with only 2 exceptions every one of my high scores on all current tables (so on 41 of the 43 tables at the time of writing) are within the top 10%, so my intense loathing of this game is nothing to do with me being crap at it.

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I've always loved pinball. As a child, I'd always gravitate to them and feed as many quarters in their gullet as my parents would provide. I loved the sounds, the feel of the flippers, the glittering LED screens and flashing lights. The time was over too quickly. So when I saw the free-to-play Pinball FX2 hit Steam, I downloaded it immediately. It's easy to understand the notion of FX2: a digital platform for tables that are too fantastical for the real world. It's a great idea. But it doesn't quite deliver. The tables are imaginative, bright and colorful, and sometimes unique. Something is missing, though. Something that's hard to explain. I think it all boils down to three main problems: sound, physics, and table design.Part of the splendor of pinball is the pings, pongs, bings, clanks, and bangs of the steel bearing flying around the arena. In large part, those tiny sounds are simply not present. You hit a target, and you hear nothing. Some flippers don't flip. The ball pangs off of a bumper, and the sound is stunted and dull. Even the ball itself sounds like a hollow piece of hardwood. It's not right. It's not the pinball I know. The sound is bad, but the physics add another layer of non-realism to the escapade. The ball tends to accelerate too quickly. When it hits a lower bumper, it barely makes it to the adjacent. It's as if the ball itself is tired. If you hit a ramp without enough speed, there's no hangtime. It almost immediately reverses direction and comes back at you with full force. It feels completely wrong.The tables generally look spactacular at first glance. Characters are animated, the lights are in the right places, and there are decorative nuances that look great. It's mostly window dressing. Once the ball is launched, you immediately notice problems. Most tables lack a proper skillshot, or the ball simply shoots across the table into a boring location only to be flipped back up into a myriad of lazy ramps. And boy do the designers love ramps. Several tables are almost completely composed of them. Ramps are a core part of pinball, but there needs to be balance. You need targets, flippers, spinners, bumpers, and above all: goals.All of the tables have goals. They are just hard - or frustrating - to find. They need to be more obvious. It's no fun to throw the ball around for 10 minutes without hearing a single mission from the horribly acted announcers. When you manage to find one, they don't pay off. There's no feel of advancement.I had high hopes. Probably too high. Pinball FX2 didn't deliver.There is a game, though, for my fellow pinball fans: Pinball Arcade (also on Steam). You get one table free and are able to try any of the rest until you hit a reasonable score cap. Each table is painstakingly digitalized from a real, beloved machine. And it shows. The care taken into recreation is obvious at every turn. The physics are -perfect-. The tables, in general, are a complete blast to play. The snippets of history attached before you play a table makes you fully understand the attention the developers put into the game of pinball. They love it in real life and wanted to express it digitally. They fully succeeded. The tables are pricy, but entirely worth the money.Play Pinball Arcade. Don't play FX2.

Posted: March 11, 2014
												This is probably the most blatant use of "free-to-play" I've ever seen. You can only play one table. That's it. Just one. At least Pinball Arcade also threw in a free table you could play for a month. But this one gives you no sort of freebie. And the one table you CAN play is rather bleh IMO.I played the table a couple times and it got boring quickly. The voices are obnoxious and the music was kinda bland. Sure there were extra "mini tables" but I got ejected back to the main table before I could even figure out what I was supposed to do! Give me a redo for the love of God!The fact that all of the tables cost over $100 just makes me want to bang my head on a wall. I could use that money to buy all the games on my Wishlist and still have money left over!All I want out of Steam is a non-demo free game that doesn't contain microtransactions to unlock other features. I'm very low on funds and I'm trying to use it wisely, but is a Steam game that doesn't ask for money every five seconds too hard to make? If you want a decent Steam pinball game, go with Pinball Arcade. Not this Marvel-whoring, money-grabbing game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Probably the worst pinball game I have ever played. Firt off there is an unnaturally long delay between pushing your buttons and seeing something happen on the table. It's something like 0.2 to 0.3 seconds which in any multiplayer FPS would be an extreme lag. The ball is also quite erratic. It can speed up to maybe triple speed for no reason (until it properly hits something, then it resets back to normal). It may also slow down quite a lot without any proper reason and then again reset back to normal after a proper hit. There's something horribly wrong with the physics engine. Sometimes the ball may just also lose all momentum by having a slight touch to some element. I've played horribly many various pinballs during my about 30 year gaming career but never seen a pinball with this many Oddities.Also many tables have too much visual clutter that makes it much more difficult to spot either the balls or targets to shoot at but that is nothing new in the genre.

number of helpful: 15 of 40 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Way too difficult and time-consuming to be worth playing.I have about 20 tables that I've picked up through sales and such over time. Sure, the game involves batting a ball around. Sure, you get points. But this is about as much pinball as Sonic Spinball was. Every single table has a ridiculously drawn out set of goals you have to meet to get anywhere near the final mode. How is anyone supposed to clear Fear Itself, Inifinity Gauntlet, or Star Wars Ep. 4 within any kind of reasonable time? Look at classic pins like Addams Family, Twilight Zone, Monster Bash, Tales of the Arabain Nights, or Theatre of Magic. Someone who knows what they're doing can get through all of the modes and into the wizard mode with about 15 minutes of playing. When I go to YouTube, every single table's wizard mode takes at least 50 minutes to over an hour of (what I assume to be) truly excellent playing. Star Wars Ep. 5? Gotta get through six separate stages of three checkpoints each. Fear Itself? Hope you like clearing the... seven(?) worthies. Don't mess up that last shot, or you have to start the whole mode over. Infinity Gauntlet? THERE ARE MORE PEOPLE ALIVE TODAY THAN HAVE EVER DIED. DID YOU KNOW THAT? ADAM WARLOCK WILL MAKE SURE YOU DON'T FORGET. I tried changing the difficulty of the tables, but I don't see that it does anything. Some ball saver time limits might be increased, but the modes aren't any easier to complete. You'd think that somewhere around "very easy", they'd do something like allow you to pick up where you left off during a given mode. Timeshock, Big Race USA and Fantastic Journey by Pro Pinball are great examples of challenging games with reasonable goals and measureable progress through them. I want to like these tables. I really do. They're all good-looking and some of them are pretty clever. But holy balls, they take forever to feel like you've accomplished anything. Some people might say "Learn to play, noob. These tables are meant to be hard." I counter that there's a sport called Takraw which is like volleyball with nothing but bicycle kicks. It's a ridiculuosly hard sport to play. Does that make it the best sport in the world? Is Checkers better than Chess? Is American Football better than Soccer? More difficult doesn't make something better.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												PFX2 is excellent.  There are companies making full sized pinball tables (look up Watson's in Cincinnati) which you stand at and play like the real machines.  This will be my 2016 project.  And Zen/Microsoft knows it!  They just added 'cabinet support' to allow multiple screens for the playfield, backglass, and LCDs to make the stand up game.  I've played PFX2 on my computer for a couple of years now, and I have had the luck of running into a stand up pinball machine converted to play these tables - and it is incredible.  Picture driving a Nascar game and then sitting in one and taking a few laps.....but forget all that if you have no chance at building a table or buying one.  It is still, hands down, the best pinball experience you will have on your PC.  I personally am a pinball junkie and have Pinball Arcade, Future Pinball, and VpinMAME on my machine.  Each one has things I like about them.  VpinMAME and Pinball Arcade will scratch every old-school itch you could have (for us who grew up in arcades), but FP has more updated graphics and opened up new, creative table design.All this said, PFX2 has THE best looks of all of them, way more game feel - like you are playing a multi-tiered video game while you're playing pinball, the 2010+ vs. the 1970s/80s feel, and is priced like they just want to share a bite of their pizza instead of trying to get me to buy the whole thing.The EULA is NOTHING.  It is no different than any other software I've installed, or anyone has, and any reviewer mentioning it has lost their mind or is working for a competitor.  The fact taht I am typing this in STEAM on Windows 7 means I've at very least signed two EULAs.  (and many more)  No one is soliciting me or has any more of my info than anyone using Windows, or a debit card, or living in the 20th century.The other 'issue' is that Zen identified an exploit which allowed PC users to use an auto program to hit a key and guarantee a lost ball save (from the center drain).  They fixed it and reset the wizard scores since several people found and used the hack to act as if they were pinball gods.  Do not let that be a second's thought in deciding to purchase the game!  An athelete who tests positive for steroids will try to go down kicking and fighting instead of coming clean.  It hurts their pride...  That is ALL that the reset complaints are about.  (it's hard to believe that it was mentioned since it zeroed in on the 'roiders'')I wrote all of this because I understand hard work - and have lived with weak whiners who didn't get their simple way trying to discredit my efforts because it went against their path of least resistance.PFX2 is free to get into!  That rocks alone.  You can stop right there if you choose - with no problem at all.  If you like it, like I do , you can choose any other table to buy and play.They made this a no-brainer, and a couple of pirates and hackers get to post against the game here (because this is the USA and we cater to cry-babies).  The game is more than solid and worth the free price.  Man, have fun with it...  How a few people are painting it as some conspiracy is as stupid as you get.

number of helpful: 4 of 20 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												I dont get this game, I play from a couch on a big 50 inch tv, and it doesnt play very well, zoomed out and its too far away, zoomed in and you cant tell where the ball is going.  Am I supposed to turn my tv on the side because the left and right which are half the screen arent even used for actual gameplay.The ball physics are terrible, I've never seen a pinball fly around like crazy like it does here.  Its so fast it could break the speed of sound, its not pinball as much as its pinball on steroids and the guy hitting the flippers has roid rage, every hit of the flipper sends the fall flying as fast as possible.  This pinball game is an oddity of science if they actually moved that way, if the ball was moving that fast and speeding up, its insane, since its free its something to be seen.  The camera moves so fast if you choose any other angle I found than top down or far away that there is no chance of hitting the ball if its zoomed in.Most of the tables my ball will often just fall down the middle, all that stuff on the table is like angled to shoot the ball right down the middle.  Some of the tables it feels like only one side of the table is relevant, with ramps while the other side seems useless, why have it there at all?  The ball is lost so much its gets tiresome having to keep relaunching the ball, adding an auto ball launcher option woulda been nice, but it isnt there and never will be so its just annoying.Rating:  2/10  Value:  $0.99 per table

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												The best binball game on PC hands down! Yes, it is that good.It runs great, it looks great, it is fun. It is addictive. A great game to play with friends locally. This is clearly made by people who loves pinball games. I have always dreamed about having my own pinball game, and I love to play the real ones when possible. But this is almost as good as the real deal, and it also adds some things that a real pinball machine would not be able to do. But all with taste and reason. It really sounds and feels like a real pinball machine.You get one table for free, so you could say that the game is free. This free table is totally ok in fact, and then you can demo all the other tables as well (as many times as you want), which is fun even though you can't play that long. Look out for deals for the other tables though if you are interested and have little cash, they come frequently. Besides, they are not that much for the full price, and they are really good and quite deep. It takes a while to really learn and master each table. But this game is also perfect for just a quick casual game when you have 5 minutes. But watch out, or that 5 minutes will become 30 minutes before you know it. It is quite addictive.The game works great with the keyboard, but I noticed it works even better with the controller, because of an added analog feel, and some feedback.You should not have any problem running this on most PCs but it still looks really nice. This is an honest well made game, and for what you get the price is totally just. If you like pinball you won't regret buying a few of the tables, guaranteed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2013
												Owning all the tables on nearly every available platform is a testiment in itself to how good this game is.  Ignore complaints of being charged with tables after beingg baited by a "free" game... is this not the trend now...?  In fact, Zen has followed this model for years, and this should be expected as such.  Certainly you will get a table for free, but they provide quality demos of each table for individuals to make their own decisions and pay for the ones the choose.  Beyond that, the tables are loosely inspired by real world tables, and carry some elements of love from their reality based counterparts, though they may not be recognizable to a younger generation (those who grew up in the absence of real tables).  The physics are getting better, but this is more of a fantasy simulation pinball.  If you are expecting anything more, than look to Pinball Arcade, a worthy mention replicating real tables.  Zen has managed to produce Pinball tables that have great rule sets, awesome challenges, and offer hours of fun, depth, skill development, and will rank you on leaderboards.  Seriously, Zen tables run about $3.00 a table.  In my experience, that is $3.00 of happiness.  Not all tables are winners, that's why they offer demos, but there's bound to be a table that everyone who claims to be a pinball fan can enjoy.  Why are you still reading...?   Give Zen a whirl, and try a table or two.  At the end of the day, you will have likely spent more money on your lunch, coffee, or some App on a phone you may hardly use.  Obviously I am a fan; however, I am a fan because the tables are worth the time.  Few games have the ability to earn my time, and like all good things... Zen will keep you coming back if you let it.

												So I've logged quite a few hours in this so far, especially if you account for the hours I've spent playing the Android equivalent, Zen Pinball HD. If you're looking for a solid pinball game on PC, I'd recommend starting here - the variety of tables for the prices is pretty darn reasonable, considering each play on a physical table would be $.25 - $.75, and even then there's no guarantee your playtime will be worth that much. And I'm usually not too big on paid DLC in games, but this is one of the few cases where there's actually a good reason for it, and it legitimately extends the game's value when purchased.TL;DR: Solid PC pinball if you don't want to mess around with configuring simulators like Visual Pinball.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												What can I say about Pinball FX 2 that hasn't already been said? Well, here's the breakdown:This is pinball. Pure, fun, addictive pinball, just as it was in the arcade, with certain elements of the game impossible on a real life pinball machine (like melting a ball in a cauldron for a locked ball).Here's the good -Lots of different tables, all with a unique feel and story.Physics are quite realistic.Graphics are mostly good, save for some (small, unobtrusive) ugly textures.You can save at any point by just hitting escape and quitting the game, and restart at that exact point, even mid ball!Here's the bad - I don't really see anything that stands out as bad with this game.I highly recommend this game to anyone that has even a passing interest in pinball, or wants something casual that has a competitive element to it. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												Surely you remember Space Cadet, right? That silly little pinball game that came pre-installed with Windows XP? Oh how you could spend hours knocking that little steel ball around, becoming ever more obsessed with beating your own high score.Consider yourself in luck; Pinball FX2 really brings pinball into the age of modern gaming! The visual effects are superb, the physics are expertly designed, and all the lights, sounds, bells, and whistles you would expect from a real pinball machine; and all of it beautifully modeled and rendered in 3D, unlike our dearly missed 2D pinball table of years gone by.Add to that a continuously growing library of tables to choose from; there's the Sorcerer's Lair table that has you wondering a haunted mansion as two kids work together to defeat the evil sorcerer that dwells within as you fight your way through skeletons, spiders, and ghouls; perhaps you'll even meet a friendly ghost to help show you the way; this table is detailed and life-like enough to make you think you're really at the arcade. There are also impossible "fantasy" tables, like Star Wars: Starfighter Assault; your table floats above a planet as you fight for either the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance; one minute you're launching your ball at the bumpers, the turbolasers on top of them blasting away at X-Wings flying above the table, the next minute you find your Star Destroyer in a heated broadside with a Rebel Star Cruiser, launching your ball into the ramps to launch fighters at the enemy; switching over to fight for the Rebels, you'll even find yourself at the controls of your X-Wing, defending your capital ships by using the flipper buttons to steer your fighter and the launch button to shoot down TIE Fighters; keep up the good work, and you may even find yourself escorting the Millenium Falcon as you attack the second Death Star above Endor. There's plenty to choose from with several more Star Wars themed tables, lots of Marvel tables featuring characters like Wolverine, Iron Man, Ghost Rider, The Avengers, and the Fantastic Four just to name a few, and even a generous selection of completely original themed tables; but no matter what you decide to play, every table presents a unique set of challenges and play quite differently from one another; and all of them are just as fun and addictive as you'd hope they'd be.What Zen Studios have done here is not just make a pinball game, they've hand-built a pinball machine in the virtual space; if you find the factory settings a bit too challenging, you can go into the Operator's Menu where you can adjust the field pitch so the ball rolls down slower, and change all kinds of difficulty settings. While you're there, you may even want to do a light and sound test to kinda get a "behind the scenes" look at the inner workings of every table.See a table you're interested in, but not quite sure you want to commit? You're free to take every table out for a trial play, to see if you like the table before adding it to your collection.Pinball FX2 may seem like little more than a nostalgia trip for those of us that grew up playing that silly little 2D pinball game on our Windows computers, and to an extent it is; but it's more than that, Pinball FX2 is really what we wanted that old Windows pinball game to be all along.

												Download this for free and get the full Sorcerer's Lair board for free. The board's theme is a little cheesy, but it'll give you an idea of what to expect from Pinball FX2. Each board is fairly unique. I picked up the Star Wars: Balance of the Force Pack at 75%, and the 3 boards you get are very well designed and quite different from each other. Posted: June 20, 2014
												An enjoyable diversion.  Not as difficult as actual pinbal tables (or the tables in pinball arcade), but they were designed to be fun and thematic rather than to eat quarters.  On the positive side there is one completely free table and you can also play any table as much as you want for free (but it wont keep track of high scores or achievements).  On the negative side, since part of the game is free to play, that means if you use steam family sharing, the game will have none of the tables you purchased on the main account, so you have to buy tables for each account you want to use it with.  I use a second account for steam family sharing on my laptop as a convenience, but for this game, its an annoynce, but the game itself is good.  In particular I recoment the core pack as I enjoy the rome and secrets of the deep tables.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Man, when I originally played the Windows Pinball game back in the 2000's, I never thought I'd find another decent free Pinball game. When I started FX2, I was greeted by the single table that sat before me. (Ok, so there are transactions to get your tables, so what? You'd blow more quarters at real Bally tables than you would buying these tables. Besides, I bought mine through Zen Studios' Humble Weekly sale.) I started the table up, and I instantly felt the nostalgia. The score board in the corner made me feel like I was actually playing at a real table. The graphics were insanely impressive; again, appearing almost as a real table. I put it aside though, because playing the same table did get boring.Though, when I started playing the new tables after the Weekly Sale, I fell in love. Avengers table, with the movie characters as balls? Yes. This. I loved this. Each set table had it's own ups and downs, (and to be honest, I haven't even finished playing all these tables yet) but I'm anxious to get more without shelling out coin. I'd really like to see Zen put out a free table, say for a week. This way, players would get a sense of what tables they'd like to buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												My first try to review a game. Sorry if my English isn't all that.GrafixDo what they have to do. They are what you can expect of this kinda games. No framedrops, some nice fx (like the trails the balls have), although they can get a little bit overwhelming. Thor's cape hiding the playing field, some Avenger balls that give some funky effect you have to get used to, but overall a 9/10. SoundEvery table has it's own soundset. This gives you a lot of variation in your audible experience. Sometimes the tables keep repeating themselves. Mister Banner, we know they killed your wife & unborn child, enough already! But this comes with this kind of game. 8/10. I missed the voices of the original actors in the Star Wars or Marvel tables.GameplayIt's pinball. Does everything what you want of a pinballgame. Personally I like my tables very life like. So turning a table upside down or the crazy animations (characters flying or throwing stuff all over the table) weren't really necesarry. But it adds a nice over the top feel that some of us will appreciate. You also can keep playing this game. Either to improve your own personnal score, local or on the leader boards, or to see if you are a better player then one of your friends. 9/10OverallYou like pinball? You'll like this game. Unsure? Play the demotables. You'll see that you want to keep playing just to see what the tables have to offer. Multiballs, over the top animations, really great arcadegameplay. Live from DoobyValley I'll give this a solid 8.5/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												What can I say about Pinball FX 2 that hasn't already been said? Well, here's the breakdown:This is pinball. Pure, fun, addictive pinball, just as it was in the arcade, with certain elements of the game impossible on a real life pinball machine (like melting a ball in a cauldron for a locked ball).Here's the good -Lots of different tables, all with a unique feel and story.Physics are quite realistic.Graphics are mostly good, save for some (small, unobtrusive) ugly textures.You can save at any point by just hitting escape and quitting the game, and restart at that exact point, even mid ball!Here's the bad - I don't really see anything that stands out as bad with this game.I highly recommend this game to anyone that has even a passing interest in pinball, or wants something casual that has a competitive element to it. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Pinball FX2 looks great, plays mostly great, and sounds great.  Most of the tables are very well designed and lots of fun to play.  "Epic Quest" is by far my favorite.I have just a few minor gripes:- the menus / UI are kind of clumsy and cluttered- a few tables are very poorly designed and not much fun- they forgot one major feature: online multiplayer!  Seriously...Overall, I like it a lot.  There is one really annoying bug though, that will cause the game to lag and stutter until you change your Nvidia/AMD control panel settings to "Max prerendered frames = 1".  It's lame that the game doesn't do this by itself, but I'm guessing they used some cheap 3D middleware that doesn't let them tweak that properly.And really, no online multiplayer ?  It does show your friends' high scores but they could have at least let us play against each other in real-time (while heckling over the voice mic, of course).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Very fun if you like pinball at all, and you can have fun without paying a cent. There's a lot of variation in table complexity and gameplay quality, even within the DLC packs themselves. I'd like to pay one price and get every table ever. You could go with free platforms like Virtual Pinball, Pinmame, Future Pinball. They have numerous tables, both emulated from real tables and new designs. But they're not on Steam and can be finicky.If the tables lack perfect physics, they make up for it with interesting features not commonly found in physical tables. In some cases they would be impossible on a real table, but they still retain the character and flavor of real pinball. The character animations, mini-games, and side-tables give you a lot to look at and do while you master a table. I can't always get a perfect camera angle it seems, so head tracking/oculus rift would help bridge the gap between this and real machines.

Posted: June 24, 2013
												This is a pretty good pinball game. There is one free table and a load of others you have to pay for. You can play a very brief demo of each of the paid for tables. But this does not give you much time to get into the game. This game brought back happy memories of the space cadet pinball on Windows XP. And much like that game if you just try to keep the ball in play there is little excitement but once you realise there are missions it opens up a whole new level of enjoyment. The graphics are very nice and there is a hidden extra table activated by certain missions. It takes a long while to get the hang of what to do and I image it would take a hell of a long time to master it. The free table is probably good for a few hours entertainment but it didn't persuade me to part with any money to play the paid for tables.

												Excellent original pinball tables that play like real tables while still taking a few liberties that could only be done in the virtual world. Excellent pinball physics; you can almost "feel" the weight of the ball. The sounds and music are superb as well and they make great use of assets on the licensed theme tables (such as the Star Wars tables). The game includes one free table and it is not simply a throwaway, it is a lot of fun to play. You also get a short amount of demo playtime on many of the other purchasable tables so there is no risk in trying this one out whether you love pinball or you're trying it for the first time.

												A great re-creation of pinball physics and 'gimmicks' (multiball, video modes, Magna Save, even TILTing), while raising the bar in a way that a real pinball cannot (moving characters, disappearing balls, one table even plays upside-down as part of a multiball mode!).  The collection is currently split three ways - a Star Wars theme, a Marvel Comics theme, and a more 'traditional' collection that evokes fond memories of real 'pins while being unique in their own way.The first table - Sorcerer's Lair - is completely free, so go ahead and give it a shot (it's my second favorite table, after Paranormal).  I'd suggest getting a controller if you're really interested though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2013
												Owning all the tables on nearly every available platform is a testiment in itself to how good this game is.  Ignore complaints of being charged with tables after beingg baited by a "free" game... is this not the trend now...?  In fact, Zen has followed this model for years, and this should be expected as such.  Certainly you will get a table for free, but they provide quality demos of each table for individuals to make their own decisions and pay for the ones the choose.  Beyond that, the tables are loosely inspired by real world tables, and carry some elements of love from their reality based counterparts, though they may not be recognizable to a younger generation (those who grew up in the absence of real tables).  The physics are getting better, but this is more of a fantasy simulation pinball.  If you are expecting anything more, than look to Pinball Arcade, a worthy mention replicating real tables.  Zen has managed to produce Pinball tables that have great rule sets, awesome challenges, and offer hours of fun, depth, skill development, and will rank you on leaderboards.  Seriously, Zen tables run about $3.00 a table.  In my experience, that is $3.00 of happiness.  Not all tables are winners, that's why they offer demos, but there's bound to be a table that everyone who claims to be a pinball fan can enjoy.  Why are you still reading...?   Give Zen a whirl, and try a table or two.  At the end of the day, you will have likely spent more money on your lunch, coffee, or some App on a phone you may hardly use.  Obviously I am a fan; however, I am a fan because the tables are worth the time.  Few games have the ability to earn my time, and like all good things... Zen will keep you coming back if you let it.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												It's kind of fun to play pinball where the designers remember that they are actually making a video game. The core pinball mechanics are all in place but there are extras that get added in that would be physically impossible with a real pinball machine. Zen Studios has done a good job at finding the balance between video game and pinball with this game.I'm still coming to terms with the various tables there are to play. It's not always clear what shots you should be working on or what progression follows a previous one. As a result, some of the tables end up feeling pretty stale in short time. I'm not going to comment on specific tables too much until I've had a chance to really get into them and determine if there's something I'm missing.Overall, this is a decent game to play that is sufficiently different from other pinball simulators to make it work spending some time getting to know.
