content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Highly recommended if you're a pinball fan. I have played some of those tables before on Nintendo 3DS, but the level of detail was too low, and the game made poor use of the dual screen. Being able to play on a properly sized monitor and seeing the tables' elements in full HD detail puts the game in another level.Pros:- Graphics: Awesome level of detail.- Physics: Convincing. Very well implemented.- Achievement System: Adds replay value to the game, if you're tired of just going for the highest score over and over. It challenges you to aim for specific objectives.- Leaderboard: Check your rank against people from all around the world, and your friends too (if you can convince them to play this game, of course).Cons:- Features: Most of the tables' designs try to simulate a real-world pinball table. There are no such things as dynamic terrain changes or multiple layers, as seen in classics like Rollerball, Pinball Quest and Epic Quest's Enigma table. So, for the casual player, replay value may seem limited, since the layout of a table will never change significantly during the game.- DLC: Tables are available separately or as part of a package, as in-app purchases. I was lucky to get this game with tons of tables in a Humble Bundle sale. But if you're not, you might end up spending some money trying to get more variety out of this game. Whether it is worth it or not, it depends on you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Solid pinball game. In many respects I like it more than the pinball arcade. While pinball FX does not design around classic pinball machines that are models made by williams, gottleib, stern or what have you. It still a great game, beyond that missing element (which might be a let down for people who have a history of playing with physical machines). While that domain is pinball arcade's forte the thing pinball arcade lacks is the solid nature of the pinball physics that is in the game pinball FX.Table designs are either original or around comic, movie franchises. While I feel its a bit overkill to have so many of these tables flood and saturate the variety tables to choose from, each table can be sampled before purchase so that you know how they work. Its good to know that they did not shirk on creativity regardless of the samey franchise they pull from. (I for one prefer the original tables, but some marvel tables have proben to be really fun to play with).You can sit and play pinball and keep the ball alive for a long time and not feel that any drains are a result of bad physics. While classic machines that you find in real life arcades can sometimes be designed around token taking, quarter munching filandry, pinball FX designs it's tables for more longterm play because it does not have to compete with those scenarios.Another fun aspect that can only be obtained through virtual pinball tables are mechanics and designs that go beyond the realms of realistic restraint. You can have models on the table react to your gameplay, you can have magically floating rails, you can put a miniature cannon in the table, you can have pinballs of ice or fire. Just things that are beyond real world design constraints, and because zen studioes realizes this we get tables and mechanics that we would not see anywhere else. I recommend this game for any pinball enthusiast and anyone interested in playing a comfortable pinball game. The guys over at Zen studios did a great job for their efforts.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												This game has good physics and graphics, you definitely get the old school pinball feeling whenyour playing on some of the tables, and yet at the same time they seamlessly integrate modern graphics to do things you could not do on a real pinball table like have the ball levitate, or a lightsabre fire up on the star wars table. Since there are many different tables you can purchase, the game can be as fun (or as unfun) as your favorite (or least favorite) table. I highly reccomend the following tables Infinity Gauntlet, Empire Strikes Back, Paranormal, Epic Quest,and my personal favorite is Fear Itself (which also comes with infinity gauntlet in the pack) I have seen many pinballs try to put effects and other things in the game, but usually when pc pinball games have done this in the past, it really takes you out the game and you feel like you are no longer playing pinball, Pinball FX2 has done a great job at giving you a genuine pinball feel but not cutting us short with the modern technology we have, Highly reccomended if you enjoy pinball!It also has great 3d support if you have a good 3d card, to bring even more realism!

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												It's the best virtual pinball game I've played in recent memory. However, the visuals could better and the controls are difficult on the PC. You can play it with a keyboard and mouse but I suggest the use of a gamepad to ease the difficulty and keep the ball in play. The tables are way too expensive. Clearly the developer shelled out some major cash for licensing but you could pay $70 or more to get all the tables and that's way too much money for a pinball game. Not to mention the "pay for" tables are really not that good. One of the best tables the developer made is the free Sorcer's Lair table. Even with all the tables I paid for, I still prefer this free offering over all the other tables I bought. I also prefer the mobile version of this game over the PC. The mobile version looks better and has way better controls. Yes, I know that's a bold statement but give both versions a try and you'll see what I mean. If you are looking for a great virtual pinball experience, this one is hard to beat.

Posted: November 24, 2013
												Well, it's a pinball game so it's not like there's a whole lot to say on the matter...I will say this though:Pinball FX2 (and its *many* add-ons) is easily the best pinball video game that I've ever played. It translates real-life pinball machines to the video-game medium flawlessly. In addition, many of the pinball machines have fantastical components/mechanisms that just wouldn't be feasible or even possible in a real-life mechanical rig. It's all perfectly executed and *very very* cool. If you like pinball video games at all, this title is where you'll ultimately end up. The sheer number of "machines"/add-ons to choose from is staggering. This title will keep you pin-balling damn near forever.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												Pinball FX2 is currently the best pinball game experience available on Steam. It's also only one of two pinball games on Steam, period, but it's still a very good game and fully worthy of your time and attention. The base game engine is free to download and comes with a single table (also for free) and with that you can play indefinitely and get a good taste for the flavor of pinball offered. Here's the important things to note:#1) Without exception these are pinball tables that could not exist in the real world. There are elements grounded in the traditional model (metal guide rails and physical bumpers arrayed about a table with defined physical limits) but then there are elements which take advantage of the "Well why not?" aspect of this virtual experience like fully animated characters, laser beams shooting at the ball, bonus games that happen outside of the base table, and even special events where the laws of physics are messed with. There's a lot of imaginative freedom to explore because of this divergence from "pure" traditional pinball. This can be a plus or a minus depending on what your expectations are going into the game.#2) I'd say that on average most of the games available are much more accessable than a real pinball machine would be.  These games aren't out to eat your quarters every three minutes, and it's quite often that I could play a single game for ten minutes at a time, which makes for a really fun experience.  You really don't have to be a pinball wizard to keep the game going for a lengthy time frame but as you get better at learning the layouts and the controls you'll find yourself better able to shoot for special bonuses.#3) There's a LOT of music and voice acting throughout these games, and it's actually EXTREMELY well done.  I was prepared to grimace and accept the voicework but in most cases I found myself actually listening and finding it to be a valuable addition to the experience. The Star Wars titles are particularly noteworthy here since they didn't use the original actors or use sound clips from the movies, instead having new actors recreate famous lines which they accomplished with precision.  #4) It's possible to muck around with the settings for each game to tailor it to different specifications or just to see what different things do. These settings can make the game easier or harder (increasing the angle of the table, changing how long a particular bonus is activated, etc.) and can also be simple cosmetic things like changing the color of the dot-matrix display.  #5) If you have the ability to do so you can also change the orientation of the game to take advantage of a vertical display. This is extremely nice since these tables are inherently taller than they are wide so vertical displays are perfect.  My desktop monitor has trouble moving into this position but my netbook is easily rotated into position which was a great thing.  I was also impressed that my netbook was easily able to play the game without any performance issues.  My only complaint is an overuse of Marvel comics licenses for the tables... I've got a couple and they're nice and all, but these titles try to impart some level of storytelling into the pinball experience and that ground wears thin pretty quickly.  In the end this is a wonderful, wonderful pinball experience and is a perfect way to spend 10 to 30 minutes at a time. There's a joyful pavlovian reaction to hitting buttons and watching a ball rolling along hitting dinging bells and moving through trap doors and slides and I'd encourage anyone to give it a try. Since the base game comes with one table for free you owe it to yourself to try it out, and for a couple bucks here and there you can add to your virtual pinball hall to bring in more fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												This game is, simply put, fun. The fact that it is a free game that you have to buy different tables for is, admittedly, annoying but that is circumvented by the fact that it gives you one of, in my personal opinion, the best tables to start off with. The fact that it starts as free to play is very nice seeing as this allows people who either don't play pinball, or haven't in the past, to have a go and see if they like it. The fact that it feels as though the ball has some weight to it and it doesn't exist in a vacuum is a welcome addition. In addition to this the leader board between friend can create a bit of friendly competition, though the Superscore and Pinball Wizard score do kind of say ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to that as they incorporate scores from other tables that friends may not personally own, though with the recent Humble Bundle sale that has allowed a few more people to get said scores up, at least if they give enough of a flying toss.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												The game is really fun, if you want to play pinball then try it for free and see how you like it. I haven't played a pinball game in over 10 years, pinball fantasies was the last one, this game made me remember how enjoyable they can be :]The one complaint I have about the game so far is that many of the tables have a superhero or movie theme, I would prefer to see more tables with other themes. Having said that, I've played several of the superhero/movie themed tables and many of them are good. There are several tables with other themes but I would like more.I like the business model, getting one table for free and being able to try every other table before buying it. It's rare today to find a game where the developers aren't trying to milk you in every way possible with DLC and various degrees of pay-to-win. Big props to Zen Studios for the fair business model.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												It's kind of fun to play pinball where the designers remember that they are actually making a video game. The core pinball mechanics are all in place but there are extras that get added in that would be physically impossible with a real pinball machine. Zen Studios has done a good job at finding the balance between video game and pinball with this game.I'm still coming to terms with the various tables there are to play. It's not always clear what shots you should be working on or what progression follows a previous one. As a result, some of the tables end up feeling pretty stale in short time. I'm not going to comment on specific tables too much until I've had a chance to really get into them and determine if there's something I'm missing.Overall, this is a decent game to play that is sufficiently different from other pinball simulators to make it work spending some time getting to know.

This game has a huge amount of replayability whether it be for getting a higher score or just refining your skills and accuracy. I highly reccomend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												Pinball FX2 is currently the best pinball game experience available on Steam. It's also only one of two pinball games on Steam, period, but it's still a very good game and fully worthy of your time and attention. The base game engine is free to download and comes with a single table (also for free) and with that you can play indefinitely and get a good taste for the flavor of pinball offered. Here's the important things to note:#1) Without exception these are pinball tables that could not exist in the real world. There are elements grounded in the traditional model (metal guide rails and physical bumpers arrayed about a table with defined physical limits) but then there are elements which take advantage of the "Well why not?" aspect of this virtual experience like fully animated characters, laser beams shooting at the ball, bonus games that happen outside of the base table, and even special events where the laws of physics are messed with. There's a lot of imaginative freedom to explore because of this divergence from "pure" traditional pinball. This can be a plus or a minus depending on what your expectations are going into the game.#2) I'd say that on average most of the games available are much more accessable than a real pinball machine would be.  These games aren't out to eat your quarters every three minutes, and it's quite often that I could play a single game for ten minutes at a time, which makes for a really fun experience.  You really don't have to be a pinball wizard to keep the game going for a lengthy time frame but as you get better at learning the layouts and the controls you'll find yourself better able to shoot for special bonuses.#3) There's a LOT of music and voice acting throughout these games, and it's actually EXTREMELY well done.  I was prepared to grimace and accept the voicework but in most cases I found myself actually listening and finding it to be a valuable addition to the experience. The Star Wars titles are particularly noteworthy here since they didn't use the original actors or use sound clips from the movies, instead having new actors recreate famous lines which they accomplished with precision.  #4) It's possible to muck around with the settings for each game to tailor it to different specifications or just to see what different things do. These settings can make the game easier or harder (increasing the angle of the table, changing how long a particular bonus is activated, etc.) and can also be simple cosmetic things like changing the color of the dot-matrix display.  #5) If you have the ability to do so you can also change the orientation of the game to take advantage of a vertical display. This is extremely nice since these tables are inherently taller than they are wide so vertical displays are perfect.  My desktop monitor has trouble moving into this position but my netbook is easily rotated into position which was a great thing.  I was also impressed that my netbook was easily able to play the game without any performance issues.  My only complaint is an overuse of Marvel comics licenses for the tables... I've got a couple and they're nice and all, but these titles try to impart some level of storytelling into the pinball experience and that ground wears thin pretty quickly.  In the end this is a wonderful, wonderful pinball experience and is a perfect way to spend 10 to 30 minutes at a time. There's a joyful pavlovian reaction to hitting buttons and watching a ball rolling along hitting dinging bells and moving through trap doors and slides and I'd encourage anyone to give it a try. Since the base game comes with one table for free you owe it to yourself to try it out, and for a couple bucks here and there you can add to your virtual pinball hall to bring in more fun.

The fact that it is a free game that you have to buy different tables for is, admittedly, annoying but that is circumvented by the fact that it gives you one of, in my personal opinion, the best tables to start off with. The fact that it feels as though the ball has some weight to it and it doesn't exist in a vacuum is a welcome addition. In addition to this the leader board between friend can create a bit of friendly competition, though the Superscore and Pinball Wizard score do kind of say ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to that as they incorporate scores from other tables that friends may not personally own, though with the recent Humble Bundle sale that has allowed a few more people to get said scores up, at least if they give enough of a flying toss.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Highly recommended if you're a pinball fan. I have played some of those tables before on Nintendo 3DS, but the level of detail was too low, and the game made poor use of the dual screen. Being able to play on a properly sized monitor and seeing the tables' elements in full HD detail puts the game in another level.Pros:- Graphics: Awesome level of detail.- Physics: Convincing. Very well implemented.- Achievement System: Adds replay value to the game, if you're tired of just going for the highest score over and over. It challenges you to aim for specific objectives.- Leaderboard: Check your rank against people from all around the world, and your friends too (if you can convince them to play this game, of course).Cons:- Features: Most of the tables' designs try to simulate a real-world pinball table. There are no such things as dynamic terrain changes or multiple layers, as seen in classics like Rollerball, Pinball Quest and Epic Quest's Enigma table. So, for the casual player, replay value may seem limited, since the layout of a table will never change significantly during the game.- DLC: Tables are available separately or as part of a package, as in-app purchases. I was lucky to get this game with tons of tables in a Humble Bundle sale. But if you're not, you might end up spending some money trying to get more variety out of this game. Whether it is worth it or not, it depends on you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												Surely you remember Space Cadet, right? That silly little pinball game that came pre-installed with Windows XP? Oh how you could spend hours knocking that little steel ball around, becoming ever more obsessed with beating your own high score.Consider yourself in luck; Pinball FX2 really brings pinball into the age of modern gaming! The visual effects are superb, the physics are expertly designed, and all the lights, sounds, bells, and whistles you would expect from a real pinball machine; and all of it beautifully modeled and rendered in 3D, unlike our dearly missed 2D pinball table of years gone by.Add to that a continuously growing library of tables to choose from; there's the Sorcerer's Lair table that has you wondering a haunted mansion as two kids work together to defeat the evil sorcerer that dwells within as you fight your way through skeletons, spiders, and ghouls; perhaps you'll even meet a friendly ghost to help show you the way; this table is detailed and life-like enough to make you think you're really at the arcade. There are also impossible "fantasy" tables, like Star Wars: Starfighter Assault; your table floats above a planet as you fight for either the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance; one minute you're launching your ball at the bumpers, the turbolasers on top of them blasting away at X-Wings flying above the table, the next minute you find your Star Destroyer in a heated broadside with a Rebel Star Cruiser, launching your ball into the ramps to launch fighters at the enemy; switching over to fight for the Rebels, you'll even find yourself at the controls of your X-Wing, defending your capital ships by using the flipper buttons to steer your fighter and the launch button to shoot down TIE Fighters; keep up the good work, and you may even find yourself escorting the Millenium Falcon as you attack the second Death Star above Endor. There's plenty to choose from with several more Star Wars themed tables, lots of Marvel tables featuring characters like Wolverine, Iron Man, Ghost Rider, The Avengers, and the Fantastic Four just to name a few, and even a generous selection of completely original themed tables; but no matter what you decide to play, every table presents a unique set of challenges and play quite differently from one another; and all of them are just as fun and addictive as you'd hope they'd be.What Zen Studios have done here is not just make a pinball game, they've hand-built a pinball machine in the virtual space; if you find the factory settings a bit too challenging, you can go into the Operator's Menu where you can adjust the field pitch so the ball rolls down slower, and change all kinds of difficulty settings. While you're there, you may even want to do a light and sound test to kinda get a "behind the scenes" look at the inner workings of every table.See a table you're interested in, but not quite sure you want to commit? You're free to take every table out for a trial play, to see if you like the table before adding it to your collection.Pinball FX2 may seem like little more than a nostalgia trip for those of us that grew up playing that silly little 2D pinball game on our Windows computers, and to an extent it is; but it's more than that, Pinball FX2 is really what we wanted that old Windows pinball game to be all along.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												I found out this game is free to play - there are 43 available tables, but you only get one off the bat, "Sorceror's Lair." Since I'm a fan of pinball games, I figured I'd give it a shot and I was quite happy with it. The physics are damn accurate, with responsive flippers and three different ways to 'nudge' the table. The tables are all 'modern' style pinball tables, with lots of ramps, lanes, and all sorts of busy animation and mini-games included. Some might find the sheer amount of motion a bit off-putting, but I got used to it quickly. Can't recommend the game highly enough if you're a silver ball enthusiast, but watch out - you might find yourself buying every table and making this 'free' game cost quite a lot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Smooth controls... precise, realistic ball physics and innovative design all make for a game that you can pick up and play casually for the fun of the moment, or push for the highest score against your friends on the leaderboard!Your skill is rewarded with an ongoing plot, and the tables I have played all have an 'end game' that provides big points and a satisfying conclusion if you can reach it.  After you do, keep going again to get there another way or simply push for a higher score!Pinball FX2 players on Steam have an extra delight in store... Sorcerer's Lair, one of their best tables according to reviewers, is free for unlimited play!  The next time you're in the mood for score pounding relaxation, you should install this and join the adventure.  You won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												What can I say about Pinball FX 2 that hasn't already been said? Well, here's the breakdown:This is pinball. Pure, fun, addictive pinball, just as it was in the arcade, with certain elements of the game impossible on a real life pinball machine (like melting a ball in a cauldron for a locked ball).Here's the good -Lots of different tables, all with a unique feel and story.Physics are quite realistic.Graphics are mostly good, save for some (small, unobtrusive) ugly textures.You can save at any point by just hitting escape and quitting the game, and restart at that exact point, even mid ball!Here's the bad - I don't really see anything that stands out as bad with this game.I highly recommend this game to anyone that has even a passing interest in pinball, or wants something casual that has a competitive element to it. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												EDIT: The EULA may have been changed, but still be warned just in case.EDIT 2: Bang backs are still possible, albeit at a reduced rate. Diagonal nudges are pointless, but there are other ways of tackling this, provided the required circumstances. Still up to you; I'm leaning towards a "MIXED" than a negative. I really enjoy this game, to be honest, but Zen's execution and message of that update is still bad.ORIGINAL: Nerfed diagonal nudging to a point where bang backs are (almost, but never actually got one) impossible. Every pinball player in Steam should know that we are now inferior compared to the console and mobile versions. The terminology used by the higher-ups, as well as even attempting to get a high score, made me temporarily quit (at least while this debacle was still fresh).Ultimately it's up to you at this point.http://steamcommunity.com/app/226980/discussions/0/490121928355358516/#c492379159709727925
